readme.content:
# Shopify App Template for Node

This is a template for building a [Shopify app](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started) using Node and React. It contains the basics for building a Shopify app.

Rather than cloning this repo, you can use your preferred package manager and the Shopify CLI with [these steps](#installing-the-template).

## Benefits

Shopify apps are built on a variety of Shopify tools to create a great merchant experience. The [create an app](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started/create) tutorial in our developer documentation will guide you through creating a Shopify app using this template.

The Node app template comes with the following out-of-the-box functionality:

- OAuth: Installing the app and granting permissions
- GraphQL Admin API: Querying or mutating Shopify admin data
- REST Admin API: Resource classes to interact with the API
- Shopify-specific tooling:
  - AppBridge
  - Polaris
  - Webhooks

## Tech Stack

This template combines a number of third party open-source tools:

- [Express](https://expressjs.com/) builds the backend.
- [Vite](https://vitejs.dev/) builds the [React](https://reactjs.org/) frontend.
- [React Router](https://reactrouter.com/) is used for routing. We wrap this with file-based routing.
- [React Query](https://react-query.tanstack.com/) queries the Admin API.
- [`i18next`](https://www.i18next.com/) and related libraries are used to internationalize the frontend.
  - [`react-i18next`](https://react.i18next.com/) is used for React-specific i18n functionality.
  - [`i18next-resources-to-backend`](https://github.com/i18next/i18next-resources-to-backend) is used to dynamically load app translations.
  - [`@formatjs/intl-localematcher`](https://formatjs.io/docs/polyfills/intl-localematcher/) is used to match the user locale with supported app locales.
  - [`@formatjs/intl-locale`](https://formatjs.io/docs/polyfills/intl-locale) is used as a polyfill for [`Intl.Locale`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Intl/Locale) if necessary.
  - [`@formatjs/intl-pluralrules`](https://formatjs.io/docs/polyfills/intl-pluralrules) is used as a polyfill for [`Intl.PluralRules`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Intl/PluralRules) if necessary.

The following Shopify tools complement these third-party tools to ease app development:

- [Shopify API library](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-node-api) adds OAuth to the Express backend. This lets users install the app and grant scope permissions.
- [App Bridge React](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/app-bridge/getting-started/using-react) adds [authentication to API requests](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/app-bridge-library/apis/resource-fetching) in the frontend and renders components outside of the App‚Äôs iFrame.
- [Polaris React](https://polaris.shopify.com/) is a powerful design system and component library that helps developers build high quality, consistent experiences for Shopify merchants.
- [File-based routing](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-frontend-template-react/blob/main/Routes.jsx) makes creating new pages easier.
- [`@shopify/i18next-shopify`](https://github.com/Shopify/i18next-shopify) is a plugin for [`i18next`](https://www.i18next.com/) that allows translation files to follow the same JSON schema used by Shopify [app extensions](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/checkout/best-practices/localizing-ui-extensions#how-it-works) and [themes](https://shopify.dev/docs/themes/architecture/locales/storefront-locale-files#usage).

## Getting started

### Requirements

1. You must [download and install Node.js](https://nodejs.org/en/download/) if you don't already have it.
1. You must [create a Shopify partner account](https://partners.shopify.com/signup) if you don‚Äôt have one.
1. You must create a store for testing if you don't have one, either a [development store](https://help.shopify.com/en/partners/dashboard/development-stores#create-a-development-store) or a [Shopify Plus sandbox store](https://help.shopify.com/en/partners/dashboard/managing-stores/plus-sandbox-store).

### Installing the template

This template can be installed using your preferred package manager:

Using yarn:

```shell
yarn create @shopify/app --template=node
```

Using npm:

```shell
npm init @shopify/app@latest -- --template=node
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
pnpm create @shopify/app@latest --template=node
```

This will clone the template and install the required dependencies.

#### Local Development

[The Shopify CLI](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/cli) connects to an app in your Partners dashboard. It provides environment variables, runs commands in parallel, and updates application URLs for easier development.

You can develop locally using your preferred package manager. Run one of the following commands from the root of your app.

Using yarn:

```shell
yarn dev
```

Using npm:

```shell
npm run dev
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
pnpm run dev
```

Open the URL generated in your console. Once you grant permission to the app, you can start development.

## Deployment

### Application Storage

This template uses [SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/index.html) to store session data. The database is a file called `database.sqlite` which is automatically created in the root. This use of SQLite works in production if your app runs as a single instance.

The database that works best for you depends on the data your app needs and how it is queried. You can run your database of choice on a server yourself or host it with a SaaS company. Here‚Äôs a short list of databases providers that provide a free tier to get started:

| Database   | Type             | Hosters                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ---------- | ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| MySQL      | SQL              | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/try/managed-databases-mysql), [Planet Scale](https://planetscale.com/), [Amazon Aurora](https://aws.amazon.com/rds/aurora/), [Google Cloud SQL](https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql) |
| PostgreSQL | SQL              | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/try/managed-databases-postgresql), [Amazon Aurora](https://aws.amazon.com/rds/aurora/), [Google Cloud SQL](https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/postgres)                                   |
| Redis      | Key-value        | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/try/managed-databases-redis), [Amazon MemoryDB](https://aws.amazon.com/memorydb/)                                                                                                        |
| MongoDB    | NoSQL / Document | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/try/managed-databases-mongodb), [MongoDB Atlas](https://www.mongodb.com/atlas/database)                                                                                                  |

To use one of these, you need to change your session storage configuration. To help, here‚Äôs a list of [SessionStorage adapter packages](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-api-js/blob/main/packages/shopify-api/docs/guides/session-storage.md).

### Build

The frontend is a single page app. It requires the `SHOPIFY_API_KEY`, which you can find on the page for your app in your partners dashboard. Paste your app‚Äôs key in the command for the package manager of your choice:

Using yarn:

```shell
cd web/frontend/ && SHOPIFY_API_KEY=REPLACE_ME yarn build
```

Using npm:

```shell
cd web/frontend/ && SHOPIFY_API_KEY=REPLACE_ME npm run build
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
cd web/frontend/ && SHOPIFY_API_KEY=REPLACE_ME pnpm run build
```

You do not need to build the backend.

## Hosting

When you're ready to set up your app in production, you can follow [our deployment documentation](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/deployment/web) to host your app on a cloud provider like [Heroku](https://www.heroku.com/) or [Fly.io](https://fly.io/).

When you reach the step for [setting up environment variables](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/deployment/web#set-env-vars), you also need to set the variable `NODE_ENV=production`.

## Known issues

### Hot module replacement and Firefox

When running the app with the CLI in development mode on Firefox, you might see your app constantly reloading when you access it.
That happened in previous versions of the CLI, because of the way HMR websocket requests work.

We fixed this issue with v3.4.0 of the CLI, so after updating it, you can make the following changes to your app's `web/frontend/vite.config.js` file:

1. Change the definition `hmrConfig` object to be:

   ```js
   const host = process.env.HOST
     ? process.env.HOST.replace(/https?:\/\//, "")
     : "localhost";

   let hmrConfig;
   if (host === "localhost") {
     hmrConfig = {
       protocol: "ws",
       host: "localhost",
       port: 64999,
       clientPort: 64999,
     };
   } else {
     hmrConfig = {
       protocol: "wss",
       host: host,
       port: process.env.FRONTEND_PORT,
       clientPort: 443,
     };
   }
   ```

1. Change the `server.host` setting in the configs to `"localhost"`:

   ```js
   server: {
     host: "localhost",
     ...
   ```

### I can't get past the ngrok "Visit site" page

When you‚Äôre previewing your app or extension, you might see an ngrok interstitial page with a warning:

```text
You are about to visit <id>.ngrok.io: Visit Site
```

If you click the `Visit Site` button, but continue to see this page, then you should run dev using an alternate tunnel URL that you run using tunneling software.
We've validated that [Cloudflare Tunnel](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-one/connections/connect-apps/run-tunnel/trycloudflare/) works with this template.

To do that, you can [install the `cloudflared` CLI tool](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-one/connections/connect-apps/install-and-setup/installation/), and run:

```shell
# Note that you can also use a different port
cloudflared tunnel --url http://localhost:3000
```

Out of the logs produced by cloudflare you will notice a https URL where the domain ends with `trycloudflare.com`. This is your tunnel URL. You need to copy this URL as you will need it in the next step.

```shell
2022-11-11T19:57:55Z INF Requesting new quick Tunnel on trycloudflare.com...
2022-11-11T19:57:58Z INF +--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
2022-11-11T19:57:58Z INF |  Your quick Tunnel has been created! Visit it at (it may take some time to be reachable):  |
2022-11-11T19:57:58Z INF |  https://randomly-generated-hostname.trycloudflare.com                                     |
2022-11-11T19:57:58Z INF +--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
```

Below you would replace `randomly-generated-hostname` with what you have copied from the terminal. In a different terminal window, navigate to your app's root and with the URL from above you would call:

```shell
# Using yarn
yarn dev --tunnel-url https://randomly-generated-hostname.trycloudflare.com:3000
# or using npm
npm run dev --tunnel-url https://randomly-generated-hostname.trycloudflare.com:3000
# or using pnpm
pnpm dev --tunnel-url https://randomly-generated-hostname.trycloudflare.com:3000
```

## Developer resources

- [Introduction to Shopify apps](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started)
- [App authentication](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/auth)
- [Shopify CLI](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/cli)
- [Shopify API Library documentation](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-api-js#readme)
- [Getting started with internationalizing your app](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/best-practices/internationalization/getting-started)
  - [i18next](https://www.i18next.com/)
    - [Configuration options](https://www.i18next.com/overview/configuration-options)
  - [react-i18next](https://react.i18next.com/)
    - [`useTranslation` hook](https://react.i18next.com/latest/usetranslation-hook)
    - [`Trans` component usage with components array](https://react.i18next.com/latest/trans-component#alternative-usage-components-array)
  - [i18n-ally VS Code extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Lokalise.i18n-ally)

Great! Here‚Äôs a solid UI plan for your **Student Leaders Directory** page to make it **clean, user-friendly, and visually appealing.**  

---

### **üìå UI Design Suggestions for the Student Leaders Directory**  

#### üé® **General Theme & Aesthetic:**  
- **Minimalist, professional, and modern** (similar to LinkedIn but campus-focused).  
- Use **card-based layouts** for student leader profiles.  
- Keep a **light or dark mode toggle** for accessibility.  

---

### **üîπ Page Layout Breakdown:**  

#### **1Ô∏è‚É£ Header (Top Navigation Bar)**
üîπ **Logo & Name** ‚Äì "Polilist" branding.  
üîπ **Search Bar** ‚Äì Find student leaders by name, position, or year.  
üîπ **Filters Button** ‚Äì Dropdown for filtering by office, year, election type.  
üîπ **Login/Profile Button** ‚Äì If you plan to allow user accounts.  

---

#### **2Ô∏è‚É£ Main Section: Student Leaders List**
üü¢ **Grid-based layout** ‚Äì Display leaders in **cards (3 or 4 per row, responsive for mobile).**  

üìå **Each Leader‚Äôs Card Includes:**  
‚úîÔ∏è **Profile Picture** (circular or square).  
‚úîÔ∏è **Name & Current Office** (e.g., John Doe ‚Äì Student Body President).  
‚úîÔ∏è **Political Affiliation (if applicable).**

üí° **Hover Effect:** On hover, the card can slightly lift and show **"View Contact"** if available.  

---

#### **3Ô∏è‚É£ Sidebar (Filters & Categories)**
- **Sort by:** Name | Office | Year | Election Result (Winner/Runner-up)  
- **Filter by:** Political Party | Past vs. Current Leaders | Faculty/Department  
- **Toggle Button for ‚ÄúShow Only Elected Leaders‚Äù**  

---

#### **4Ô∏è‚É£ Profile Page for Each Leader (Opens When Clicked)**
- **Banner with Name & Current Office.**  
- **Detailed Bio:** Achievements, past offices, affiliations.  
- **Team Members from Past Elections (Displayed Below).**  
- **Contact Section (if consented).**  

---

### **‚ú® Extra Features for a Polished Look**
‚úî **Sticky Search Bar** for easy access.  
‚úî **Mobile-Friendly Design** (Cards become vertical list).  
‚úî **Animations** ‚Äì Smooth hover effects and page transitions.

readme.content:
Thanks ‚Äî I‚Äôve fully reviewed the README you uploaded.

You're using the modern Shopify Node app template (based on Express + Vite + React + React Router), and here's what that changes for our plan:

---

## ‚úÖ Key Takeaways from the README

1. This is not "backendless" ‚Äî it still uses an Express backend under the hood (with OAuth, Admin API access, sessions, and webhooks).
2. You don't need to manually build routes like /server/routes/api.js from scratch ‚Äî Shopify CLI already wires up a working Express server with session-aware Admin API access.
3. Your backend lives under the /web directory (e.g. /web/index.js, /web/middleware).
4. You don‚Äôt need to touch the frontend inside this repo since you‚Äôve already deployed your own widget on Vercel.
5. Shopify App Bridge and Admin API functionality is still present and supported.

So your original plan (OAuth, access token storage, and Admin API product access) is still correct ‚Äî we just need to align with the newer directory structure.

---

## ‚úÖ What You Should Do Next

Now that your Shopify Node app is working and installed on your test store:

### 1. Inject Your Widget into the Storefront via ScriptTag API

This part is still 100% valid.

We'll add code to the afterAuth lifecycle in your app backend to register a ScriptTag that loads your hosted widget.js (from Vercel) into the storefront.

We‚Äôll do this inside:

üìÅ web/index.js ‚Üí in the afterAuth section

I‚Äôll walk you through that once you confirm you're ready.

‚Äî

### 2. Add Backend API Routes for Your Widget to Use

Your widget (on the storefront) will fetch:

* Product data via GET /api/products
* Checkout links via POST /api/checkout

We‚Äôll define these two routes using the Express router in:

üìÅ web/index.js or in a new üìÅ web/routes/widget.js file (I‚Äôll help set that up cleanly)

‚Äî

### 3. Secure the Routes with Session Validation

Each route will need to:

* Load the merchant session from the session store
* Use the stored access token to call the Shopify Admin or Storefront API

This logic is already handled via Shopify's SDK and middleware. We‚Äôll just reuse it.

‚Äî

‚úÖ Summary:

* You‚Äôre not backendless ‚Äî you just don‚Äôt need to manually configure Koa or separate folders anymore
* The app is Express + Vite + React under a monorepo structure (web/ folder holds everything)
* Your own storefront widget hosted on Vercel is a separate concern ‚Äî but it will now fetch from this app‚Äôs backend

‚Äî

üß≠ Next Step:

Shall I help you write the ScriptTag injection code inside web/index.js now? That‚Äôs the most direct next move.

readme.content:
# Bet Planner

Bet Planner is a modern web application for managing, planning, and tracking your sports betting slips. It allows users to create, edit, and organize prediction slips, add matches, make notes, calculate odds and expected winnings, and export slip details as PDFs. All data is stored locally in the browser using IndexedDB for privacy and offline access.

---

## Features

- **Create and Manage Prediction Slips:**  
  Start new slips, edit their details, and delete them when no longer needed.

- **Add Matches to Slips:**  
  Add upcoming matches to any slip, with support for odds, predictions, and notes per match.

- **Notes and Annotations:**  
  Add and edit notes for each match in a slip for strategy or reminders.

- **Odds and Winnings Calculation:**  
  Automatic calculation of total odds and expected winnings based on your stake and selected matches.

- **PDF Export:**  
  Export the full details of any slip (including matches and notes) as a PDF for sharing or record-keeping.

- **Local Storage with IndexedDB:**  
  All slips and match data are stored locally in your browser for privacy and offline use.

- **Modern, Responsive UI:**  
  Clean, mobile-friendly interface with intuitive navigation and helpful tooltips.

---

## Tech Stack

- **Frontend:** React (with Next.js, App Router, and client components)
- **Styling:** Tailwind CSS
- **Icons:** react-icons
- **Database:** IndexedDB (via Dexie.js)
- **PDF Generation:** jsPDF
- **State Management:** React hooks

---

## Project Structure

```
/app
  /planspace
    [slipId]/
      page.jsx         # Slip detail page (view, edit, export, manage matches)
    page.jsx           # Main planspace page (list, create, delete slips)
  /components
    PredictionSlipForm.jsx
    PredictionSlipCard.jsx
    MatchCard.jsx
    Upcoming.jsx
  /utils
    db.js              # Dexie.js IndexedDB setup
```

---

## Key Components

### 1. Planspace Page (`/app/planspace/page.jsx`)
- Lists all prediction slips.
- Allows creating new slips (‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù).
- Each slip is shown as a card with summary info and a delete button.

### 2. Prediction Slip Card (`/components/PredictionSlipCard.jsx`)
- Displays slip name, stake, target odds, expected win, and number of matches.
- ‚ÄúWork on this slip‚Äù button navigates to the slip detail page.
- Red trash icon allows deleting the slip.

### 3. Slip Detail Page (`/app/planspace/[slipId]/page.jsx`)
- Shows all details for a single slip.
- Edit stake and target odds.
- Add or remove matches.
- Add, edit, or delete notes for each match.
- View calculated total odds and expected win.
- Export slip as PDF.

### 4. MatchCard & Upcoming
- Display match details and allow adding matches to slips.

### 5. IndexedDB (`/utils/db.js`)
- All slips and matches are stored locally using Dexie.js for privacy and offline access.

---

## How to Run Locally

1. **Install dependencies:**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

2. **Run the development server:**
   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

3. **Open your browser:**
   Visit [http://localhost:3000/planspace](http://localhost:3000/planspace)

---

## Usage Guide

- **Create a Slip:**  
  Click ‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù and fill in the slip details.

- **Add Matches:**  
  Open a slip, then click ‚ÄúAdd Matches from Upcoming‚Äù to select matches.

- **Edit Details:**  
  Use the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù button to change stake or target odds.

- **Add Notes:**  
  For each match in a slip, add or edit notes for your own reference.

- **Delete a Slip:**  
  Click the red trash icon on any slip card and confirm deletion.

- **Export as PDF:**  
  In the slip detail page, click ‚ÄúExport as PDF‚Äù to download a summary of the slip.

---

## Customization

- **Styling:**  
  Tailwind CSS classes are used throughout. You can easily adjust colors, spacing, and layout in the JSX.

- **Persistence:**  
  All data is stored in the browser. To clear all data, clear your browser‚Äôs site data.

- **PDF Output:**  
  The PDF export uses jsPDF and can be customized in the `handleExportPDF` function.

---

## Screenshots

> _Add screenshots here for the main pages, slip card, and PDF export if desired._

---

## License

MIT License

---

## Credits

- [Dexie.js](https://dexie.org/) for IndexedDB management
- [jsPDF](https://github.com/parallax/jsPDF) for PDF generation
- [React Icons](https://react-icons.github.io/react-icons/) for UI icons

---

## Contributing

Pull requests and suggestions are welcome! Please open an issue or PR for improvements or bug fixes.

---

If you need more detailed API or code documentation, or want to add a FAQ or troubleshooting section, let me know!

# money_planner
### Chat link

https://chatgpt.com/share/6895d36a-5798-8009-9eaf-181e0f0563fb
### üß© Problem Statement

Many individuals struggle with understanding where their money goes each month. They often rely on mental accounting or scattered notes to track income, expenses, and savings goals ‚Äî resulting in financial leaks and poor planning. **Money Planner** solves this by offering a visual, intuitive whiteboard-style interface that helps users:

* Track income sources
* Manage daily expenses
* Set and monitor savings goals
* View total available cash at a glance

---

### üì± App Pages and Screens

---

#### 1. **HomeWhiteboard (Money Canvas)**

> `lib/pages/home_whiteboard.dart`

**Purpose:**
Visual overview of a user's financial flows.

**Components:**

* **Income Nodes**: Display income sources with name and amount.
* **Expense Nodes**: Display expense items similarly.
* **Goal Nodes**: Show savings goals with a progress bar.
* **Money Pot Summary**: A highlighted card showing the total available cash based on income minus expenses and goals.
* **Dynamic Data Fetching**: Uses Drift + StreamBuilders/FutureBuilders to reflect live financial data.

**Problem Solved:**
Presents a bird's-eye view of the user's money, making financial status understandable in seconds.

---

#### 2. **Onboarding/Startup Check**

> `lib/main.dart` or wherever the app initializes

**Purpose:**
Ensure that a user profile exists before continuing.

**Implementation:**

* On app startup, check if a user exists.
* If not, insert a default user with a zero `moneyPot`.

**Problem Solved:**
Prevents null reference errors and prepares the app with a base user profile.

---

### üóÉÔ∏è Drift Database Structure

---

#### 1. **Users Table**

```dart
class Users extends Table {
  IntColumn get id => integer().autoIncrement()();
  TextColumn get name => text().withDefault(const Constant('Default User'))();
  RealColumn get moneyPot => real().withDefault(const Constant(0.0))();
}
```

**Problem Solved:**
Central place to store and update the user's total available cash, used throughout the app.

---

#### 2. **IncomeSources Table**

Stores all income streams:

* `id`
* `name`
* `amount`

**Problem Solved:**
Keeps track of where money is coming from, with ability to add/remove/edit.

---

#### 3. **Expenses Table**

Stores all expense records:

* `id`
* `name`
* `amount`

**Problem Solved:**
Helps track where money is going, which is essential for budgeting.

---

#### 4. **Goals Table**

Tracks saving objectives:

* `id`
* `name`
* `targetAmount`
* `currentAmount`

**Problem Solved:**
Encourages users to allocate funds toward future goals (e.g. vacation, emergency fund).

---

#### 5. **WishlistItems Table**

Allows users to add potential future purchases or savings ideas.

**Problem Solved:**
Supports planning and impulse control by listing desires separately from goals and expenses.

---

### üîß Methods & Features

---

#### ‚úÖ `getTotalMoneyPot()`

* Computes the user‚Äôs current pot from stored value.
* Used in `MoneyPot` card.

#### ‚úÖ `updateMoneyPot(double newAmount)`

* Updates the user‚Äôs pot manually.
* Called when income/expense/goal changes are significant.

#### ‚úÖ `checkOrCreateDefaultUser()`

* Called on app start to ensure user exists.

---

# dev_brief

To create a simple and valuable Flutter app with SQLite for developers to manage their local projects, you need to focus on delivering the most essential information and designing an intuitive first screen. Since the app launches automatically when the laptop or desktop starts and operates locally, it should provide a quick, actionable overview of all local projects and their statuses. Below, I‚Äôll outline the key information to prioritize and how to structure the UI for the first screen to maximize its usefulness.

### Information to Prioritize
For the app to be valuable, it should focus on the following pieces of information, which are critical for developers to manage their projects effectively:

- **Project Name**: This is the primary identifier for each project, making it easy for the developer to recognize their work at a glance.
- **Status**: Clearly indicate whether a project is **unfinished**, **dead**, or **finished**. This helps the developer quickly assess which projects require attention or can be ignored.
- **Last Launched Date**: Show the date when the project was last opened through the app. This provides insight into recent activity and helps prioritize tasks, reflecting the developer‚Äôs interaction with the project via this tool.
- **Project Path**: Store the file system path to the project directory. This is essential for enabling the "Launch in VS Code" feature, allowing seamless access to the project.

These elements ensure the app delivers concise, actionable data without overwhelming the user.

### UI Structure for the First Screen
The first screen should be clean, intuitive, and focused on providing an immediate overview of projects, with quick access to key actions for unfinished projects. Here‚Äôs how it should be structured:

#### **App Bar**
- **Title**: Display the app name (e.g., "Project Manager") to provide context.
- **Settings Icon**: Include an icon (e.g., a gear) on the right side that opens a settings page. This allows the developer to configure options like the VS Code executable path or app preferences.

#### **Filter Tabs**
- Provide a row of filter tabs below the app bar to sort projects by status:
  - **All**: Shows every project regardless of status.
  - **Unfinished**: Displays only unfinished projects (set as the default view).
  - **Dead**: Shows projects marked as dead.
  - **Finished**: Lists completed projects.
- **Default View**: Set to "Unfinished" since these are the projects most likely needing attention when the developer starts their device. This focuses the app on actionable tasks right away.

#### **Project Cards**
- Use a scrollable list of cards to display projects based on the selected filter. Each card should include:
  - **Project Name**: In bold text for emphasis and easy scanning.
  - **Status**: Displayed with color-coding for quick recognition:
    - Yellow for **unfinished** (indicating active work).
    - Red for **dead** (signaling abandonment).
    - Green for **finished** (showing completion).
  - **Last Launched Date**: Shown as "Last Launched: [date]" to indicate the last time the project was opened via the app.
  - **Actions for Unfinished Projects**:
    - **"Launch in VS Code" Button**: A button that opens the project directory in VS Code using the stored project path.
    - **Gravestone Icon**: A clickable icon (e.g., a tombstone) to mark the project as dead, updating its status in the database after a confirmation prompt.

#### **Optional Enhancements**
- **Search Bar**: Add a search field above the project list to let developers quickly find projects by name, enhancing usability for those with many projects.
- **Project Counters**: Display a count in the app bar or near the filter tabs (e.g., "Unfinished Projects: 5") to give an instant sense of workload.

### Why This Works
- **Prioritized Information**: The focus on project name, status, last launched date, and path ensures the developer gets the most relevant details without clutter. The "Last Launched" date, updated when a project is opened via the app, keeps the info practical and tied to app usage.
- **UI Design**: The app bar, filter tabs, and project cards create a structured, glanceable interface. Defaulting to unfinished projects aligns with the developer‚Äôs likely intent‚Äîstarting work‚Äîwhile color-coded statuses and action buttons make it fast and easy to act on projects.
- **Local Focus**: Since all operations are local, the SQLite database (with a simple table for id, name, status, path, and last_launched) and Flutter‚Äôs lightweight widgets ensure quick startup and responsiveness, fitting the autostart requirement.

This approach delivers a valuable tool that simplifies project management, keeps the developer focused, and integrates seamlessly into their workflow.

Unlike Trello or Notion, it‚Äôs purpose-built for **code projects stored on your machine.**

---

## üìÑ README / Elevator Pitch

You can paste this into your GitHub README:

---

# üöÄ \[Your App Name] ‚Äì A Personal Side Project Manager for Developers

**\[Your App Name]** is a clean, local-first desktop app built to help **solo developers** manage their side projects more efficiently.

Whether you're exploring a new idea, building a utility, or working on a long-term product ‚Äî this app gives you a lightweight command center for everything you're shipping *from your own machine*.

---

## üß† Why It Exists

Most task managers (like Trello, Notion, ClickUp) are designed for teams or generic tasks. But developers have unique needs:

* Your projects live in **folders**, not "cards"
* You juggle **ideas, repos, todos, and experiments**
* You often want **no cloud**, **no login**, and **no distractions**

---

## ‚ú® Features

* üìÇ **Add local project folders**
* üìù **Attach metadata**: description, tag (learning, monetization, etc.), priority
* ‚úÖ **Track tasks** per project (TODOs, fixes, enhancements)
* üåë **Dark mode**, clean UI, distraction-free UX
* üîó **Optional GitHub link** per project
* üß† **Everything is stored locally** with SQLite (via Drift)

---

## üîí Designed for Solo Devs

* No team collaboration bloat
* No cloud sync unless *you* want it
* Just a simple dashboard for *you and your code*

---

## üîß Built With

* Flutter (Desktop)
* Drift (SQLite)
* `dart:io` for file access

---

## üì¶ Coming Soon

* üß† Language detection (detect if a project is Python, Flutter, etc.)
* üóëÔ∏è Project archiving
* üîî Smart reminders (e.g. "Haven‚Äôt touched this in 7 days")
* üìà Personal progress stats

---

## üõ†Ô∏è Perfect for

* Hackathon projects
* Experiments
* Startups in stealth
* Weekend apps
* Your own code garden üå±

---

## üì∑ Screenshots

*(Add screenshots when ready)*

---

## üß™ Philosophy

> Don‚Äôt over-plan your projects. Track the essentials. Ship more.

# Orthopedic Health Center Landing Page Checklist
CLAUDE CHAT-NESHJESSE
## Header & Navigation
- [ ] Clear, professional logo prominently displayed
- [ ] Contact information (phone number) visible in header
- [ ] Simple navigation menu (About, Services, Contact)
- [ ] Location indicator (Nairobi/Kenya) for local trust
- [ ] WhatsApp contact option (popular in Kenya)

## Hero Section
- [ ] Compelling headline that addresses main pain points
- [ ] Subheadline explaining your unique value proposition
- [ ] High-quality hero image of modern clinic or happy patients
- [ ] Primary CTA button: "Book Appointment Now" (prominently placed)
- [ ] Trust indicators (years of experience, patient count)

## Social Proof & Credibility
- [ ] Patient testimonials with real names and photos
- [ ] Before/after case studies (where appropriate)
- [ ] Professional certifications and qualifications
- [ ] Medical board registrations
- [ ] Awards or recognitions
- [ ] Google reviews/ratings display

## Services Section
- [ ] Clear list of conditions treated (back pain, joint problems, sports injuries)
- [ ] Treatment options available
- [ ] Specializations highlighted
- [ ] Icons or visuals for each service
- [ ] Brief descriptions in simple, non-medical language

## About the Doctors
- [ ] Professional photos of doctors
- [ ] Qualifications and experience
- [ ] Specializations clearly stated
- [ ] Years of practice
- [ ] Training background (local and international)

## Appointment Booking
- [ ] Multiple prominent "Book Appointment" CTAs throughout page
- [ ] Online booking system integration
- [ ] Alternative booking options (phone, WhatsApp)
- [ ] Clear indication of available appointment times
- [ ] Emergency contact information
- [ ] Insurance acceptance information

## Location & Contact
- [ ] Clear address with landmarks (important in Nairobi)
- [ ] Interactive Google Maps embed
- [ ] Directions from major areas/landmarks
- [ ] Parking information
- [ ] Public transport accessibility
- [ ] Operating hours clearly displayed

## Kenya-Specific Considerations
- [ ] NHIF acceptance clearly stated
- [ ] Other local insurance partnerships
- [ ] Pricing transparency (consultation fees)
- [ ] Mobile money payment options (M-Pesa, Airtel Money)
- [ ] Multilingual support if needed (English/Kiswahili)
- [ ] Local medical regulatory compliance mentions

## Technical & UX Elements
- [ ] Mobile-responsive design (majority of Kenyan users on mobile)
- [ ] Fast loading times (consider slower internet speeds)
- [ ] Click-to-call phone numbers
- [ ] WhatsApp click-to-chat integration
- [ ] SSL certificate for security
- [ ] Privacy policy and data protection compliance

## Content & Messaging
- [ ] Pain points addressed (chronic pain, mobility issues, sports injuries)
- [ ] Benefits-focused copy rather than feature-focused
- [ ] Urgency creators ("Don't let pain limit your life")
- [ ] Risk reversals ("Consultation satisfaction guarantee")
- [ ] Clear value propositions
- [ ] FAQ section addressing common concerns

## Visual Design
- [ ] Clean, medical/professional color scheme (blues, whites, greens)
- [ ] High-quality, relevant imagery
- [ ] Consistent branding throughout
- [ ] Scannable layout with plenty of white space
- [ ] Professional typography that's easy to read
- [ ] Accessibility considerations

## Conversion Optimization
- [ ] A/B test different CTA button colors and text
- [ ] Multiple conversion paths (booking, consultation, contact)
- [ ] Exit-intent popups with special offers
- [ ] Retargeting pixel installation
- [ ] Analytics tracking setup
- [ ] Heat mapping tools for user behavior analysis

## Trust & Safety
- [ ] Medical licenses and certifications displayed
- [ ] Data protection and privacy statements
- [ ] Patient confidentiality assurances
- [ ] COVID-19 safety protocols
- [ ] Sterilization and hygiene standards

# LLM Prompt for Orthopedic Health Center Landing Page

Create a high-converting landing page for an orthopedic health center targeting Kenyan patients. The primary goal is to drive appointment bookings through our online booking system.

## Context & Audience:
- **Target Audience**: Kenyan adults (25-65) experiencing joint pain, back problems, sports injuries, or mobility issues
- **Primary Device**: Mobile-first design (80% of users will access via smartphone)
- **Location**: Nairobi, Kenya
- **Primary Action**: Book an appointment online
- **Secondary Actions**: Call clinic, WhatsApp inquiry

## Brand Positioning:
- Modern, professional orthopedic clinic
- Expert care with international standards
- Accessible and patient-focused
- Trusted by the Nairobi community

## Required Sections & Content:

### 1. Header
- Clinic logo and name
- Phone number with click-to-call: +254 XXX XXX XXX
- WhatsApp button
- "Book Appointment" CTA button

### 2. Hero Section
**Headline**: "Get Back to Pain-Free Living - Expert Orthopedic Care in Nairobi"
**Subheadline**: "Don't let joint pain, back problems, or sports injuries limit your life. Our experienced orthopedic specialists provide world-class treatment with personalized care."
- Large "Book Your Consultation Today" button
- Hero image: Modern clinic interior or confident doctor with patient
- Trust indicator: "Over 5,000+ successful treatments"

### 3. Services Section
**Title**: "Comprehensive Orthopedic Care for All Your Needs"
Services to highlight:
- Back & Spine Treatment
- Joint Replacement (Knee, Hip)
- Sports Injury Recovery
- Arthritis Management
- Fracture Care
- Physical Rehabilitation

### 4. Why Choose Us
- Board-certified orthopedic surgeons
- 15+ years of combined experience
- State-of-the-art diagnostic equipment
- NHIF accepted + major insurance partners
- Same-day consultations available
- M-Pesa payment accepted

### 5. Doctor Profiles
- Professional photos
- Dr. [Name]: MB ChB (University of Nairobi), Fellowship in Joint Replacement
- Specializations and experience
- "Your health is our priority" messaging

### 6. Patient Testimonials
Include 2-3 testimonials with:
- Patient names and photos (with permission)
- Specific conditions treated
- Results achieved
- 5-star rating display

### 7. Appointment Booking Section
**Headline**: "Take the First Step Towards Recovery"
- Prominent booking form or button linking to online system
- "Quick 2-minute booking process"
- Available time slots indicator
- Alternative contact methods (phone, WhatsApp)

### 8. Location & Contact
- Full address: [Your Address], Nairobi
- Google Maps embed
- "Near [Major Landmark]" for easy identification
- Operating hours: Mon-Fri 8AM-6PM, Sat 9AM-2PM
- Parking available
- Accessible by matatu from [major stages]

### 9. Footer
- Contact information
- Social media links
- Privacy policy
- Medical license numbers

## Design Requirements:
- **Color Scheme**: Professional medical colors (navy blue, white, light blue accents)
- **Typography**: Clean, readable fonts (minimum 16px on mobile)
- **Mobile Optimization**: Touch-friendly buttons, easy scrolling
- **Loading Speed**: Optimized images, minimal code
- **Accessibility**: High contrast, alt text for images

## Kenyan Market Specific Features:
- NHIF logo and "We Accept NHIF" prominently displayed
- M-Pesa payment option mentioned
- WhatsApp integration for inquiries
- Local landmarks for location reference
- Mobile-first approach (slow internet consideration)
- Consultation fees clearly stated (e.g., "Initial Consultation: KSh 3,000")

## Call-to-Action Strategy:
- Primary CTA: "Book Appointment Now" (blue button, repeated 3-4 times)
- Secondary CTA: "Call Now: +254 XXX XXX XXX"
- WhatsApp CTA: "Chat with Us on WhatsApp"
- Emergency contact clearly visible

## Trust & Credibility Elements:
- Medical Council of Kenya registration
- Professional certifications
- Years of experience badges
- Patient success statistics
- Google Reviews integration
- COVID-19 safety protocols

## Content Tone:

# shipmate

 A Personal Side Project Manager for Developers

**\[Your App Name]** is a clean, local-first desktop app built to help **solo developers** manage their side projects more efficiently.

Whether you're exploring a new idea, building a utility, or working on a long-term product ‚Äî this app gives you a lightweight command center for everything you're shipping *from your own machine*.

---

## üß† Why It Exists

Most task managers (like Trello, Notion, ClickUp) are designed for teams or generic tasks. But developers have unique needs:

* Your projects live in **folders**, not "cards"
* You juggle **ideas, repos, todos, and experiments**
* You often want **no cloud**, **no login**, and **no distractions**

---

## ‚ú® Features

* üìÇ **Add local project folders**
* üìù **Attach metadata**: description, tag (learning, monetization, etc.), priority
* ‚úÖ **Track tasks** per project (TODOs, fixes, enhancements)
* üåë **Dark mode**, clean UI, distraction-free UX
* üîó **Optional GitHub link** per project
* üß† **Everything is stored locally** with SQLite (via Drift)

---

## üîí Designed for Solo Devs

* No team collaboration bloat
* No cloud sync unless *you* want it
* Just a simple dashboard for *you and your code*

---

## üîß Built With

* Flutter (Desktop)
* Drift (SQLite)
* `dart:io` for file access

---

## üì¶ Coming Soon

* üß† Language detection (detect if a project is Python, Flutter, etc.)
* üóëÔ∏è Project archiving
* üîî Smart reminders (e.g. "Haven‚Äôt touched this in 7 days")
* üìà Personal progress stats

---

## üõ†Ô∏è Perfect for

* Hackathon projects
* Experiments
* Startups in stealth
* Weekend apps
* Your own code garden üå±

---

## üì∑ Screenshots

*(Add screenshots when ready)*

---

## üß™ Philosophy

> Don‚Äôt over-plan your projects. Track the essentials. Ship more.

---

Let me know if you‚Äôve picked a name ‚Äî I can adjust this copy and turn it into a landing page draft or GitHub README with badges, instructions, and styling.

Would you like help with:

* Choosing the final name and logo tagline?
* Creating screenshots and sample projects to bundle?
* Generating a one-page **landing site**?

We can go full indie-product launch mode if you want.

### üî• What is Cave Keeper?

Cave Keeper is a lightweight desktop app for developers who have a thousand folders named *"myapp-final-v2-real-2"*.
It scans your computer‚Äôs project directories (starting with your Desktop) and turns chaos into clarity ‚Äî with smart tagging, tech detection, and a dead-simple dashboard.

* Focus only on what matters today

### üõ†Ô∏è Built With

readme.content:
# Bet Planner

Bet Planner is a modern web application for managing, planning, and tracking your sports betting slips. It allows users to create, edit, and organize prediction slips, add matches, make notes, calculate odds and expected winnings, and export slip details as PDFs. All data is stored locally in the browser using IndexedDB for privacy and offline access.

---

## Features

- **Create and Manage Prediction Slips:**  
  Start new slips, edit their details, and delete them when no longer needed.

- **Add Matches to Slips:**  
  Add upcoming matches to any slip, with support for odds, predictions, and notes per match.

- **Notes and Annotations:**  
  Add and edit notes for each match in a slip for strategy or reminders.

- **Odds and Winnings Calculation:**  
  Automatic calculation of total odds and expected winnings based on your stake and selected matches.

- **PDF Export:**  
  Export the full details of any slip (including matches and notes) as a PDF for sharing or record-keeping.

- **Local Storage with IndexedDB:**  
  All slips and match data are stored locally in your browser for privacy and offline use.

- **Modern, Responsive UI:**  
  Clean, mobile-friendly interface with intuitive navigation and helpful tooltips.

---

## Tech Stack

- **Frontend:** React (with Next.js, App Router, and client components)
- **Styling:** Tailwind CSS
- **Icons:** react-icons
- **Database:** IndexedDB (via Dexie.js)
- **PDF Generation:** jsPDF
- **State Management:** React hooks

---

## Project Structure

```
/app
  /planspace
    [slipId]/
      page.jsx         # Slip detail page (view, edit, export, manage matches)
    page.jsx           # Main planspace page (list, create, delete slips)
  /components
    PredictionSlipForm.jsx
    PredictionSlipCard.jsx
    MatchCard.jsx
    Upcoming.jsx
  /utils
    db.js              # Dexie.js IndexedDB setup
```

---

## Key Components

### 1. Planspace Page (`/app/planspace/page.jsx`)
- Lists all prediction slips.
- Allows creating new slips (‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù).
- Each slip is shown as a card with summary info and a delete button.

### 2. Prediction Slip Card (`/components/PredictionSlipCard.jsx`)
- Displays slip name, stake, target odds, expected win, and number of matches.
- ‚ÄúWork on this slip‚Äù button navigates to the slip detail page.
- Red trash icon allows deleting the slip.

### 3. Slip Detail Page (`/app/planspace/[slipId]/page.jsx`)
- Shows all details for a single slip.
- Edit stake and target odds.
- Add or remove matches.
- Add, edit, or delete notes for each match.
- View calculated total odds and expected win.
- Export slip as PDF.

### 4. MatchCard & Upcoming
- Display match details and allow adding matches to slips.

### 5. IndexedDB (`/utils/db.js`)
- All slips and matches are stored locally using Dexie.js for privacy and offline access.

---

## How to Run Locally

1. **Install dependencies:**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

2. **Run the development server:**
   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

3. **Open your browser:**
   Visit [http://localhost:3000/planspace](http://localhost:3000/planspace)

---

## Usage Guide

- **Create a Slip:**  
  Click ‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù and fill in the slip details.

- **Add Matches:**  
  Open a slip, then click ‚ÄúAdd Matches from Upcoming‚Äù to select matches.

- **Edit Details:**  
  Use the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù button to change stake or target odds.

- **Add Notes:**  
  For each match in a slip, add or edit notes for your own reference.

- **Delete a Slip:**  
  Click the red trash icon on any slip card and confirm deletion.

- **Export as PDF:**  
  In the slip detail page, click ‚ÄúExport as PDF‚Äù to download a summary of the slip.

---

## Customization

- **Styling:**  
  Tailwind CSS classes are used throughout. You can easily adjust colors, spacing, and layout in the JSX.

- **Persistence:**  
  All data is stored in the browser. To clear all data, clear your browser‚Äôs site data.

- **PDF Output:**  
  The PDF export uses jsPDF and can be customized in the `handleExportPDF` function.

---

## Screenshots

> _Add screenshots here for the main pages, slip card, and PDF export if desired._

---

## License

MIT License

---

## Credits

- [Dexie.js](https://dexie.org/) for IndexedDB management
- [jsPDF](https://github.com/parallax/jsPDF) for PDF generation
- [React Icons](https://react-icons.github.io/react-icons/) for UI icons

---

## Contributing

Pull requests and suggestions are welcome! Please open an issue or PR for improvements or bug fixes.

---

If you need more detailed API or code documentation, or want to add a FAQ or troubleshooting section, let me know!

# money_planner
### Chat link

https://chatgpt.com/share/6895d36a-5798-8009-9eaf-181e0f0563fb
### üß© Problem Statement

Many individuals struggle with understanding where their money goes each month. They often rely on mental accounting or scattered notes to track income, expenses, and savings goals ‚Äî resulting in financial leaks and poor planning. **Money Planner** solves this by offering a visual, intuitive whiteboard-style interface that helps users:

* Track income sources
* Manage daily expenses
* Set and monitor savings goals
* View total available cash at a glance

---

### üì± App Pages and Screens

---

#### 1. **HomeWhiteboard (Money Canvas)**

> `lib/pages/home_whiteboard.dart`

**Purpose:**
Visual overview of a user's financial flows.

**Components:**

* **Income Nodes**: Display income sources with name and amount.
* **Expense Nodes**: Display expense items similarly.
* **Goal Nodes**: Show savings goals with a progress bar.
* **Money Pot Summary**: A highlighted card showing the total available cash based on income minus expenses and goals.
* **Dynamic Data Fetching**: Uses Drift + StreamBuilders/FutureBuilders to reflect live financial data.

**Problem Solved:**
Presents a bird's-eye view of the user's money, making financial status understandable in seconds.

---

#### 2. **Onboarding/Startup Check**

> `lib/main.dart` or wherever the app initializes

**Purpose:**
Ensure that a user profile exists before continuing.

**Implementation:**

* On app startup, check if a user exists.
* If not, insert a default user with a zero `moneyPot`.

**Problem Solved:**
Prevents null reference errors and prepares the app with a base user profile.

---

### üóÉÔ∏è Drift Database Structure

---

#### 1. **Users Table**

```dart
class Users extends Table {
  IntColumn get id => integer().autoIncrement()();
  TextColumn get name => text().withDefault(const Constant('Default User'))();
  RealColumn get moneyPot => real().withDefault(const Constant(0.0))();
}
```

**Problem Solved:**
Central place to store and update the user's total available cash, used throughout the app.

---

#### 2. **IncomeSources Table**

Stores all income streams:

* `id`
* `name`
* `amount`

**Problem Solved:**
Keeps track of where money is coming from, with ability to add/remove/edit.

---

#### 3. **Expenses Table**

Stores all expense records:

* `id`
* `name`
* `amount`

**Problem Solved:**
Helps track where money is going, which is essential for budgeting.

---

#### 4. **Goals Table**

Tracks saving objectives:

* `id`
* `name`
* `targetAmount`
* `currentAmount`

**Problem Solved:**
Encourages users to allocate funds toward future goals (e.g. vacation, emergency fund).

---

#### 5. **WishlistItems Table**

Allows users to add potential future purchases or savings ideas.

**Problem Solved:**
Supports planning and impulse control by listing desires separately from goals and expenses.

---

### üîß Methods & Features

---

#### ‚úÖ `getTotalMoneyPot()`

* Computes the user‚Äôs current pot from stored value.
* Used in `MoneyPot` card.

#### ‚úÖ `updateMoneyPot(double newAmount)`

* Updates the user‚Äôs pot manually.
* Called when income/expense/goal changes are significant.

#### ‚úÖ `checkOrCreateDefaultUser()`

* Called on app start to ensure user exists.

---

readme.content:
# Simple Private Vault
A tiny, cross‚Äëplatform file encrypter that keeps sensitive photos/videos out of casual search and prying eyes.

### What it does
- Encrypts your selected files and folders (recursively) into a **hidden vault** folder.
- Uses industry‚Äëstandard crypto (Fernet: AES + HMAC via `cryptography`).
- Stores encrypted blobs with **random filenames** so original names don‚Äôt leak.
- Keeps an **encrypted manifest** of original names/relative paths (not visible to search).
- Makes a **best‚Äëeffort** to keep the vault out of Windows Search / Spotlight / Linux indexers.
- On Linux/Ubuntu, tightens permissions: vault dir `700`; key/manifest/blobs `600`.

### What it **doesn‚Äôt** do
- Bulletproof, forensic‚Äëlevel secrecy. It‚Äôs meant to keep kids/guests/friends from stumbling across things in File Explorer/Finder/Tracker search.
- Guaranteed secure deletion. Wiping files on SSDs is tricky; see Tips below.

---

## Install
1. Install Python 3.9+.
2. Install deps:
   ```bash
   pip install -r requirements.txt
   ```

## Quick start
```bash
# 1) Create a vault + key file (or use a passphrase)
python simple_vault.py init

# 2) Encrypt files/folders into the vault (recursively)
python simple_vault.py encrypt "D:\Pictures\College Party" --wipe   # Windows example
python simple_vault.py encrypt ~/Movies/PrivateClips --wipe         # macOS/Linux example
# Ubuntu/Linux example from Desktop project folder
python3 simple_vault.py encrypt ~/Downloads/GooglePhotos/ --wipe

# 3) See what‚Äôs stored (from encrypted manifest)
python simple_vault.py list

# 4) Restore files when you need them
python simple_vault.py decrypt --output ~/Restored
```

### Where is the vault?
- **Windows:** `%APPDATA%\SystemData\.vault` (marked *hidden*, *system*, *not content indexed*).
- **macOS:** `~/Library/PrivateVault.noindex` (Spotlight ignores `*.noindex`; folder is also hidden).
- **Linux/Ubuntu:** `~/.private_vault` (drops `.nomedia` & `.hidden` markers and sets perms to `700`).

You can override the location with `--vault <path>` on any command.

### Key vs Passphrase
- **Key file (default):** A `vault.key` is created inside the vault. **Back it up** to a USB or password manager.
- **Passphrase mode:** Use `--passphrase` to avoid a key file; you‚Äôll be prompted each time.

> Lose the key/passphrase = permanent data loss. There‚Äôs no backdoor.

### Keep it out of search (best effort)
- **Windows:** vault folder is `hidden + system + not content indexed`. Also placed under `AppData\Roaming` to reduce visibility.
- **macOS:** vault ends with `.noindex` so Spotlight won‚Äôt index it. We also mark it hidden.
- **Linux/Ubuntu:** dot‚Äëfolder with `.nomedia`/`.hidden` and restrictive perms `700`. Desktop indexers vary by distro; most skip hidden folders.

### Tips for safer deletion
- Use `--wipe` to best‚Äëeffort overwrite originals before deleting (okay for HDDs; SSDs are tricky).
- For stronger deletion:
  - **Windows:** run `sdelete` from Microsoft Sysinternals on the source folders.
  - **macOS/Linux:** use `shred` on HDDs. For SSDs, rely on encryption, then securely erase the device if ever needed.

### Examples
```bash
# Encrypt a single file
python simple_vault.py encrypt ~/Pictures/IMG_1234.JPG --wipe

# Encrypt a folder (recursively)
python simple_vault.py encrypt "D:\Camera Uploads" --wipe --flatten
python simple_vault.py encrypt ~/Downloads/GooglePhotos --wipe

# Decrypt to a specific folder
python simple_vault.py decrypt --output "D:\Private Restore"
python simple_vault.py decrypt --output ~/Restored

# By default, subfolders are preserved under the output directory
python simple_vault.py decrypt --output ~/Restored

# Or flatten (dump all files into one folder)
python simple_vault.py decrypt --output ~/Restored --flatten
```

### FAQ
**Q: Will File Explorer / Finder search find my private files?**  
A: No‚Äîthe originals are encrypted into a hidden vault with randomized names, and the vault is marked to avoid indexing. This keeps them out of casual search. (An expert with admin tools could still find the vault exists.)

**Q: Can I move the vault to an external drive?**  
A: Yes. Use `--vault X:\SomeHiddenFolder` (Windows) or `/Volumes/Drive/Hidden.noindex` (macOS), then `init` there and `encrypt` as usual.

**Q: Can I use one vault on two laptops?**  
A: Yes, but share the **same** key or passphrase. Keep good backups.

**Q: What video/photo apps can open files inside the vault?**  
A: None. Files are encrypted. Decrypt first into a temporary folder, view, then delete when done.

**Q: How are paths stored in the manifest now?**  
A: Paths are stored relative to the encrypted root(s). On decrypt, the original sub‚Äëfolder structure is recreated under your chosen output directory unless you pass `--flatten`.

---

**IMPORTANT:** Test with a couple of dummy files first and back up your key. This tool is intended for convenience privacy, not adversarial protection against forensics.
headings: 1) Create a vault + key file (or use a passphrase)
Ubuntu/Linux example from Desktop project folder
4) Restore files when you need them
Keep it out of search (best effort)
By default, subfolders are preserved under the output directory
Or flatten (dump all files into one folder)

readme.content:
# Bet Planner

Bet Planner is a modern web application for managing, planning, and tracking your sports betting slips. It allows users to create, edit, and organize prediction slips, add matches, make notes, calculate odds and expected winnings, and export slip details as PDFs. All data is stored locally in the browser using IndexedDB for privacy and offline access.

---

## Features

- **Create and Manage Prediction Slips:**  
  Start new slips, edit their details, and delete them when no longer needed.

- **Add Matches to Slips:**  
  Add upcoming matches to any slip, with support for odds, predictions, and notes per match.

- **Notes and Annotations:**  
  Add and edit notes for each match in a slip for strategy or reminders.

- **Odds and Winnings Calculation:**  
  Automatic calculation of total odds and expected winnings based on your stake and selected matches.

- **PDF Export:**  
  Export the full details of any slip (including matches and notes) as a PDF for sharing or record-keeping.

- **Local Storage with IndexedDB:**  
  All slips and match data are stored locally in your browser for privacy and offline use.

- **Modern, Responsive UI:**  
  Clean, mobile-friendly interface with intuitive navigation and helpful tooltips.

---

## Tech Stack

- **Frontend:** React (with Next.js, App Router, and client components)
- **Styling:** Tailwind CSS
- **Icons:** react-icons
- **Database:** IndexedDB (via Dexie.js)
- **PDF Generation:** jsPDF
- **State Management:** React hooks

---

## Project Structure

```
/app
  /planspace
    [slipId]/
      page.jsx         # Slip detail page (view, edit, export, manage matches)
    page.jsx           # Main planspace page (list, create, delete slips)
  /components
    PredictionSlipForm.jsx
    PredictionSlipCard.jsx
    MatchCard.jsx
    Upcoming.jsx
  /utils
    db.js              # Dexie.js IndexedDB setup
```

---

## Key Components

### 1. Planspace Page (`/app/planspace/page.jsx`)
- Lists all prediction slips.
- Allows creating new slips (‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù).
- Each slip is shown as a card with summary info and a delete button.

### 2. Prediction Slip Card (`/components/PredictionSlipCard.jsx`)
- Displays slip name, stake, target odds, expected win, and number of matches.
- ‚ÄúWork on this slip‚Äù button navigates to the slip detail page.
- Red trash icon allows deleting the slip.

### 3. Slip Detail Page (`/app/planspace/[slipId]/page.jsx`)
- Shows all details for a single slip.
- Edit stake and target odds.
- Add or remove matches.
- Add, edit, or delete notes for each match.
- View calculated total odds and expected win.
- Export slip as PDF.

### 4. MatchCard & Upcoming
- Display match details and allow adding matches to slips.

### 5. IndexedDB (`/utils/db.js`)
- All slips and matches are stored locally using Dexie.js for privacy and offline access.

---

## How to Run Locally

1. **Install dependencies:**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

2. **Run the development server:**
   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

3. **Open your browser:**
   Visit [http://localhost:3000/planspace](http://localhost:3000/planspace)

---

## Usage Guide

- **Create a Slip:**  
  Click ‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù and fill in the slip details.

- **Add Matches:**  
  Open a slip, then click ‚ÄúAdd Matches from Upcoming‚Äù to select matches.

- **Edit Details:**  
  Use the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù button to change stake or target odds.

- **Add Notes:**  
  For each match in a slip, add or edit notes for your own reference.

- **Delete a Slip:**  
  Click the red trash icon on any slip card and confirm deletion.

- **Export as PDF:**  
  In the slip detail page, click ‚ÄúExport as PDF‚Äù to download a summary of the slip.

---

## Customization

- **Styling:**  
  Tailwind CSS classes are used throughout. You can easily adjust colors, spacing, and layout in the JSX.

- **Persistence:**  
  All data is stored in the browser. To clear all data, clear your browser‚Äôs site data.

- **PDF Output:**  
  The PDF export uses jsPDF and can be customized in the `handleExportPDF` function.

---

## Screenshots

> _Add screenshots here for the main pages, slip card, and PDF export if desired._

---

## License

MIT License

---

## Credits

- [Dexie.js](https://dexie.org/) for IndexedDB management
- [jsPDF](https://github.com/parallax/jsPDF) for PDF generation
- [React Icons](https://react-icons.github.io/react-icons/) for UI icons

---

## Contributing

Pull requests and suggestions are welcome! Please open an issue or PR for improvements or bug fixes.

---

If you need more detailed API or code documentation, or want to add a FAQ or troubleshooting section, let me know!

# money_planner
### Chat link

https://chatgpt.com/share/6895d36a-5798-8009-9eaf-181e0f0563fb
### üß© Problem Statement

Many individuals struggle with understanding where their money goes each month. They often rely on mental accounting or scattered notes to track income, expenses, and savings goals ‚Äî resulting in financial leaks and poor planning. **Money Planner** solves this by offering a visual, intuitive whiteboard-style interface that helps users:

* Track income sources
* Manage daily expenses
* Set and monitor savings goals
* View total available cash at a glance

---

### üì± App Pages and Screens

---

#### 1. **HomeWhiteboard (Money Canvas)**

> `lib/pages/home_whiteboard.dart`

**Purpose:**
Visual overview of a user's financial flows.

**Components:**

* **Income Nodes**: Display income sources with name and amount.
* **Expense Nodes**: Display expense items similarly.
* **Goal Nodes**: Show savings goals with a progress bar.
* **Money Pot Summary**: A highlighted card showing the total available cash based on income minus expenses and goals.
* **Dynamic Data Fetching**: Uses Drift + StreamBuilders/FutureBuilders to reflect live financial data.

**Problem Solved:**
Presents a bird's-eye view of the user's money, making financial status understandable in seconds.

---

#### 2. **Onboarding/Startup Check**

> `lib/main.dart` or wherever the app initializes

**Purpose:**
Ensure that a user profile exists before continuing.

**Implementation:**

* On app startup, check if a user exists.
* If not, insert a default user with a zero `moneyPot`.

**Problem Solved:**
Prevents null reference errors and prepares the app with a base user profile.

---

### üóÉÔ∏è Drift Database Structure

---

#### 1. **Users Table**

```dart
class Users extends Table {
  IntColumn get id => integer().autoIncrement()();
  TextColumn get name => text().withDefault(const Constant('Default User'))();
  RealColumn get moneyPot => real().withDefault(const Constant(0.0))();
}
```

**Problem Solved:**
Central place to store and update the user's total available cash, used throughout the app.

---

#### 2. **IncomeSources Table**

Stores all income streams:

* `id`
* `name`
* `amount`

**Problem Solved:**
Keeps track of where money is coming from, with ability to add/remove/edit.

---

#### 3. **Expenses Table**

Stores all expense records:

* `id`
* `name`
* `amount`

**Problem Solved:**
Helps track where money is going, which is essential for budgeting.

---

#### 4. **Goals Table**

Tracks saving objectives:

* `id`
* `name`
* `targetAmount`
* `currentAmount`

**Problem Solved:**
Encourages users to allocate funds toward future goals (e.g. vacation, emergency fund).

---

#### 5. **WishlistItems Table**

Allows users to add potential future purchases or savings ideas.

**Problem Solved:**
Supports planning and impulse control by listing desires separately from goals and expenses.

---

### üîß Methods & Features

---

#### ‚úÖ `getTotalMoneyPot()`

* Computes the user‚Äôs current pot from stored value.
* Used in `MoneyPot` card.

#### ‚úÖ `updateMoneyPot(double newAmount)`

* Updates the user‚Äôs pot manually.
* Called when income/expense/goal changes are significant.

#### ‚úÖ `checkOrCreateDefaultUser()`

* Called on app start to ensure user exists.

---

Let me know if you‚Äôd like to:

* Add a **feature roadmap** section
* Include **installation instructions**
* Export this as a `README.md` file
* Add screenshots or diagrams to the README

We can build it out further!

# üßæ GanjiBoard - Technical Documentation

## üìã Project Overview

**GanjiBoard** is a web-based infinite canvas application for visual financial planning and collaborative budgeting. It combines the flexibility of a digital whiteboard with structured financial tracking capabilities.

**Current Version**: MVP v1.2
**Status**: In Development

---

## üéØ Core Value Proposition

Visual, collaborative financial planning that bridges the gap between spreadsheet precision and whiteboard flexibility.

---

## üèóÔ∏è Architecture & Tech Stack

### Frontend
- **Framework**: React 18 + Vite
- **Canvas Rendering**: React-Konva (Canvas-based)
- **Styling**: TailwindCSS
- **Icons**: React Icons (Fa*)
- **State Management**: React Hooks (useState, useEffect)

### Data Persistence
- **Primary Storage**: IndexedDB via localForage
- **Fallback**: localStorage (legacy)
- **File Operations**: JSON import/export

### Deployment
- **Platform**: Vercel/Netlify compatible
- **Build Tool**: Vite
- **Package Manager**: npm/yarn

---

## üß© Core Features Implemented

### 1. Infinite Canvas System
- **Konva-based Stage**: Infinite drag-and-drop canvas
- **Grid Background**: 40px grid with alignment guides
- **Responsive Design**: Adapts to window size

### 2. Multi-Type Card System
#### Budget Cards
- **Types**: Income (green), Expense (red), Savings (blue)
- **Properties**: Title, amount, category, frequency, notes
- **Visual**: Color-coded with type badges

#### Shopping List Cards
- **Properties**: Title, items array, total cost field
- **Interactivity**: Checkable items, strikethrough completion
- **Visual**: Purple theme with item checklist

#### Wishlist Cards
- **Properties**: Title, items with priorities (high/medium/low)
- **Visual**: Orange theme with priority indicators

### 3. Connection System
- **Arrow Connections**: Visual links between cards
- **Connection Tool**: Click-to-connect workflow
- **Data Model**: { id, fromId, toId } structure
- **Persistence**: Saved and restored with board state

### 4. Data Persistence
- **Auto-save**: Debounced 500ms save on state changes
- **IndexedDB Storage**: localForage wrapper for robust storage
- **Import/Export**: Full JSON board state backup/restore
- **Clear Functionality**: Complete board reset

### 5. Tool System
- **Toolbar**: Select, Connect, Draw, Text tools (UI ready)
- **Sidebar**: Card creation form with type-specific fields
- **Interaction Modes**: Drag, connect, create workflows

---

## üìä Data Models

### Card Object
```typescript
interface BaseCard {
  id: string;
  cardType: 'budget' | 'shopping' | 'wishlist';
  title: string;
  x: number;
  y: number;
}

interface BudgetCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'budget';
  type: 'income' | 'expense' | 'savings';
  amount: number | string;
  category: string;
  frequency: string;
  notes: string;
}

interface ShoppingCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'shopping';
  items: Array<{ name: string; checked: boolean }>;
  totalCost?: string;
}

interface WishlistCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'wishlist';
  items: Array<{ name: string; priority: 'high' | 'medium' | 'low' }>;
}
```

### Board State
```typescript
interface BoardState {
  cards: Array<BudgetCard | ShoppingCard | WishlistCard>;
  connections: Array<{
    id: string;
    fromId: string;
    toId: string;
  }>;
}
```

---

## üöÄ User Workflows

### 1. Board Creation
1. User opens app ‚Üí Loads last state from IndexedDB
2. Starts with empty canvas or previous work

### 2. Card Management
1. Click "+" button ‚Üí Opens sidebar
2. Select card type ‚Üí Shows type-specific form
3. Fill details ‚Üí Card appears on canvas
4. Drag to position ‚Üí Auto-saves position

### 3. Connection Creation
1. Select "Connect" tool ‚Üí Click first card ‚Üí Click second card
2. Arrow created ‚Üí Returns to Select tool
3. Auto-saves connection

### 4. Collaboration Preparation
1. Export board ‚Üí Downloads JSON file
2. Share file ‚Üí Others import into their GanjiBoard
3. Manual collaboration via file sharing

---

## üîß Technical Implementation Details

### Storage Service (`src/utils/storage.js`)
- **localForage Integration**: Async IndexedDB operations
- **Error Handling**: Graceful fallbacks and user feedback
- **Data Validation**: JSON schema validation on import
- **Performance**: Debounced saves to prevent UI blocking

### Component Structure
```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App.jsx                 # Main application wrapper
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CanvasBoard.jsx         # Konva stage and layers
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ toolbar.jsx             # Tool selection UI
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sidebar.jsx             # Card creation form
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ namebar.jsx             # Branding header
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ budgetCard.jsx          # Budget card renderer
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ shoplist.jsx            # Shopping list card renderer
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ wishlist.jsx            # Wishlist card renderer
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ connLayer.jsx           # Connection arrows renderer
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ storage.js              # Persistence layer
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ firebase.js                 # Future Firebase integration
```

### Performance Considerations
- **Konva Optimization**: Separate layers for grid/cards/connections
- **Render Efficiency**: Virtualized rendering for large boards
- **Memory Management**: Efficient card object handling
- **Debounced Operations**: Prevents excessive re-renders

---

## üåü Future Roadmap

### Phase 2: Collaboration Features
- **Real-time Sync**: WebSocket-based live collaboration
- **User Presence**: Avatar indicators and cursor sharing
- **Comments & Annotations**: Card-specific discussion threads
- **Version History**: Board snapshot and restore points

### Phase 3: Business Features
- **Export Formats**: Excel, CSV, PDF reporting
- **Accounting Integration**: QuickBooks/Xero connectivity
- **Advanced Analytics**: Financial insights and projections
- **Template System**: Pre-built board templates

### Phase 4: Platform Expansion
- **Mobile App**: React Native implementation
- **API Access**: Developer platform and integrations
- **Marketplace**: Community templates and extensions
- **Enterprise Features**: SSO, audit logs, compliance

---

## üõ°Ô∏è Security & Privacy

### Current Implementation
- **Client-side Only**: All data stays on user's device
- **No Tracking**: Zero analytics or data collection
- **Export Control**: User controls what they share

### Future Considerations
- **E2E Encryption**: For cloud-synced boards
- **Permission System**: View/edit/comment permissions
- **Data Residency**: Region-specific storage options
- **GDPR Compliance**: Data export and deletion tools

---

## üìà Scalability Considerations

### Current Architecture
- **Client-side Processing**: Minimal server requirements
- **Static Hosting**: CDN-friendly build output
- **Progressive Enhancement**: Works offline-first

### Future Scaling
- **Microservices**: Separate auth, storage, real-time services
- **CDN Optimization**: Asset delivery optimization
- **Database Sharding**: User-based data partitioning
- **Caching Strategy**: Intelligent client-side caching

---

## üîç Development Status

### ‚úÖ Completed
- [x] Infinite canvas with grid
- [x] Multi-type card system
- [x] Drag-and-drop functionality
- [x] Connection system with arrows
- [x] IndexedDB persistence
- [x] Import/export functionality
- [x] Responsive design

### üöß In Progress
- [ ] Real-time collaboration
- [ ] Advanced card interactions
- [ ] Mobile optimization
- [ ] Template system

### üìã Backlog
- [ ] User authentication
- [ ] Cloud synchronization
- [ ] Advanced reporting
- [ ] Integration ecosystem

---

## üé® Design Philosophy

**GanjiBoard** follows a "visual first" approach:
- **Intuitive**: No training required for basic usage
- **Flexible**: Adapts to various financial scenarios
- **Collaborative**: Designed for shared financial planning
- **Extensible**: Modular architecture for future features

---

This document will be maintained and updated as GanjiBoard evolves from a personal project to a full-featured collaborative financial planning platform.

# dev_brief

To create a simple and valuable Flutter app with SQLite for developers to manage their local projects, you need to focus on delivering the most essential information and designing an intuitive first screen. Since the app launches automatically when the laptop or desktop starts and operates locally, it should provide a quick, actionable overview of all local projects and their statuses. Below, I‚Äôll outline the key information to prioritize and how to structure the UI for the first screen to maximize its usefulness.

### Information to Prioritize
For the app to be valuable, it should focus on the following pieces of information, which are critical for developers to manage their projects effectively:

- **Project Name**: This is the primary identifier for each project, making it easy for the developer to recognize their work at a glance.
- **Status**: Clearly indicate whether a project is **unfinished**, **dead**, or **finished**. This helps the developer quickly assess which projects require attention or can be ignored.
- **Last Launched Date**: Show the date when the project was last opened through the app. This provides insight into recent activity and helps prioritize tasks, reflecting the developer‚Äôs interaction with the project via this tool.
- **Project Path**: Store the file system path to the project directory. This is essential for enabling the "Launch in VS Code" feature, allowing seamless access to the project.

These elements ensure the app delivers concise, actionable data without overwhelming the user.

### UI Structure for the First Screen
The first screen should be clean, intuitive, and focused on providing an immediate overview of projects, with quick access to key actions for unfinished projects. Here‚Äôs how it should be structured:

#### **App Bar**
- **Title**: Display the app name (e.g., "Project Manager") to provide context.
- **Settings Icon**: Include an icon (e.g., a gear) on the right side that opens a settings page. This allows the developer to configure options like the VS Code executable path or app preferences.

#### **Filter Tabs**
- Provide a row of filter tabs below the app bar to sort projects by status:
  - **All**: Shows every project regardless of status.
  - **Unfinished**: Displays only unfinished projects (set as the default view).
  - **Dead**: Shows projects marked as dead.
  - **Finished**: Lists completed projects.
- **Default View**: Set to "Unfinished" since these are the projects most likely needing attention when the developer starts their device. This focuses the app on actionable tasks right away.

#### **Project Cards**
- Use a scrollable list of cards to display projects based on the selected filter. Each card should include:
  - **Project Name**: In bold text for emphasis and easy scanning.
  - **Status**: Displayed with color-coding for quick recognition:
    - Yellow for **unfinished** (indicating active work).
    - Red for **dead** (signaling abandonment).
    - Green for **finished** (showing completion).
  - **Last Launched Date**: Shown as "Last Launched: [date]" to indicate the last time the project was opened via the app.
  - **Actions for Unfinished Projects**:
    - **"Launch in VS Code" Button**: A button that opens the project directory in VS Code using the stored project path.
    - **Gravestone Icon**: A clickable icon (e.g., a tombstone) to mark the project as dead, updating its status in the database after a confirmation prompt.

#### **Optional Enhancements**
- **Search Bar**: Add a search field above the project list to let developers quickly find projects by name, enhancing usability for those with many projects.
- **Project Counters**: Display a count in the app bar or near the filter tabs (e.g., "Unfinished Projects: 5") to give an instant sense of workload.

### Why This Works
- **Prioritized Information**: The focus on project name, status, last launched date, and path ensures the developer gets the most relevant details without clutter. The "Last Launched" date, updated when a project is opened via the app, keeps the info practical and tied to app usage.
- **UI Design**: The app bar, filter tabs, and project cards create a structured, glanceable interface. Defaulting to unfinished projects aligns with the developer‚Äôs likely intent‚Äîstarting work‚Äîwhile color-coded statuses and action buttons make it fast and easy to act on projects.
- **Local Focus**: Since all operations are local, the SQLite database (with a simple table for id, name, status, path, and last_launched) and Flutter‚Äôs lightweight widgets ensure quick startup and responsiveness, fitting the autostart requirement.

This approach delivers a valuable tool that simplifies project management, keeps the developer focused, and integrates seamlessly into their workflow.

Based on the README and project structure, here's how the app will work when a user opens their computer:

## User Scenario: Developer Starts Their Day

### 1. **Computer Boots Up**
- The app **auto-starts** in the background
- SQLite database loads with all saved projects
- App window appears on screen (likely minimized to system tray or taskbar)

### 2. **App Launches - Dashboard Screen**
```

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App Bar: "dev_brief" + Settings Icon
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Filter Tabs: [All] [Unfinished] [Dead] [Finished]
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Project Counter: "Unfinished Projects: 5"
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Search Bar: "Search projects..."
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Project Cards List (Default: Unfinished projects)
```

### 3. **What the Developer Sees**
The dashboard shows **unfinished projects by default** (most actionable):

**Project Card Example:**
```
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ My Flutter App (Unfinished) üü°      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ Last Launched: 2024-01-15           ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ [Launch in VS Code] [üóø Mark Dead]  ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

### 4. **Developer Actions**
- **Quick Scan**: Developer sees 5 unfinished projects at a glance
- **Launch Project**: Clicks "Launch in VS Code" ‚Üí VS Code opens with project
- **Mark Dead**: Clicks gravestone icon ‚Üí Project status changes to "Dead" (red)
- **Switch Views**: Can filter to see all projects, dead, or finished ones
- **Search**: Types project name to quickly find specific project

### 5. **File Scanning Feature**
The `features/file_scan/` handles:
- **Auto-discovery**: Scans common dev directories for new projects
- **Path Detection**: Identifies project roots (looks for `.git`, `pubspec.yaml`, etc.)
- **Database Sync**: Adds new projects to SQLite database
- **Status Updates**: Updates "last launched" timestamps

### 6. **Settings Integration**
Developer can configure:
- VS Code executable path
- Auto-scan directories
- App startup behavior
- Theme preferences

### 7. **Quotes Widget**
A motivational widget shows:
```
"The magic you are looking for is in the work you are avoiding"
```
- Appears on dashboard or as a separate tab
- Provides motivation to tackle unfinished projects

## Key Workflow Benefits:
1. **Immediate Focus**: Shows unfinished work first (what needs attention)
2. **Quick Access**: One-click VS Code launch
3. **Project Cleanup**: Easy way to mark dead projects
4. **Local & Fast**: No internet needed, instant startup
5. **Always Available**: Auto-starts with computer

## Technical Flow:
```
Computer Boot ‚Üí App Auto-starts ‚Üí Load SQLite DB ‚Üí 
Show Dashboard ‚Üí Display Unfinished Projects ‚Üí 
User Clicks "Launch" ‚Üí Update last_launched ‚Üí 
Open VS Code ‚Üí User works on project
```
