# Bet Planner

Bet Planner is a modern web application for managing, planning, and tracking your sports betting slips. It allows users to create, edit, and organize prediction slips, add matches, make notes, calculate odds and expected winnings, and export slip details as PDFs. All data is stored locally in the browser using IndexedDB for privacy and offline access.

---

## Features

- **Create and Manage Prediction Slips:**  
  Start new slips, edit their details, and delete them when no longer needed.

- **Add Matches to Slips:**  
  Add upcoming matches to any slip, with support for odds, predictions, and notes per match.

- **Notes and Annotations:**  
  Add and edit notes for each match in a slip for strategy or reminders.

- **Odds and Winnings Calculation:**  
  Automatic calculation of total odds and expected winnings based on your stake and selected matches.

- **PDF Export:**  
  Export the full details of any slip (including matches and notes) as a PDF for sharing or record-keeping.

- **Local Storage with IndexedDB:**  
  All slips and match data are stored locally in your browser for privacy and offline use.

- **Modern, Responsive UI:**  
  Clean, mobile-friendly interface with intuitive navigation and helpful tooltips.

---

## Tech Stack

- **Frontend:** React (with Next.js, App Router, and client components)
- **Styling:** Tailwind CSS
- **Icons:** react-icons
- **Database:** IndexedDB (via Dexie.js)
- **PDF Generation:** jsPDF
- **State Management:** React hooks

---

## Project Structure

```
/app
  /planspace
    [slipId]/
      page.jsx         # Slip detail page (view, edit, export, manage matches)
    page.jsx           # Main planspace page (list, create, delete slips)
  /components
    PredictionSlipForm.jsx
    PredictionSlipCard.jsx
    MatchCard.jsx
    Upcoming.jsx
  /utils
    db.js              # Dexie.js IndexedDB setup
```

---

## Key Components

### 1. Planspace Page (`/app/planspace/page.jsx`)
- Lists all prediction slips.
- Allows creating new slips (‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù).
- Each slip is shown as a card with summary info and a delete button.

### 2. Prediction Slip Card (`/components/PredictionSlipCard.jsx`)
- Displays slip name, stake, target odds, expected win, and number of matches.
- ‚ÄúWork on this slip‚Äù button navigates to the slip detail page.
- Red trash icon allows deleting the slip.

### 3. Slip Detail Page (`/app/planspace/[slipId]/page.jsx`)
- Shows all details for a single slip.
- Edit stake and target odds.
- Add or remove matches.
- Add, edit, or delete notes for each match.
- View calculated total odds and expected win.
- Export slip as PDF.

### 4. MatchCard & Upcoming
- Display match details and allow adding matches to slips.

### 5. IndexedDB (`/utils/db.js`)
- All slips and matches are stored locally using Dexie.js for privacy and offline access.

---

## How to Run Locally

1. **Install dependencies:**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

2. **Run the development server:**
   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

3. **Open your browser:**
   Visit [http://localhost:3000/planspace](http://localhost:3000/planspace)

---

## Usage Guide

- **Create a Slip:**  
  Click ‚ÄúCook slip‚Äù and fill in the slip details.

- **Add Matches:**  
  Open a slip, then click ‚ÄúAdd Matches from Upcoming‚Äù to select matches.

- **Edit Details:**  
  Use the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù button to change stake or target odds.

- **Add Notes:**  
  For each match in a slip, add or edit notes for your own reference.

- **Delete a Slip:**  
  Click the red trash icon on any slip card and confirm deletion.

- **Export as PDF:**  
  In the slip detail page, click ‚ÄúExport as PDF‚Äù to download a summary of the slip.

---

## Customization

- **Styling:**  
  Tailwind CSS classes are used throughout. You can easily adjust colors, spacing, and layout in the JSX.

- **Persistence:**  
  All data is stored in the browser. To clear all data, clear your browser‚Äôs site data.

- **PDF Output:**  
  The PDF export uses jsPDF and can be customized in the `handleExportPDF` function.

---

## Screenshots

> _Add screenshots here for the main pages, slip card, and PDF export if desired._

---

## License

MIT License

---

## Credits

- [Dexie.js](https://dexie.org/) for IndexedDB management
- [jsPDF](https://github.com/parallax/jsPDF) for PDF generation
- [React Icons](https://react-icons.github.io/react-icons/) for UI icons

---

## Contributing

Pull requests and suggestions are welcome! Please open an issue or PR for improvements or bug fixes.

---

If you need more detailed API or code documentation, or want to add a FAQ or troubleshooting section, let me know!

# Portfolio-OPs Technical Documentation

**Version:** 1.0.0  
**Last Updated:** September 30, 2025

---

## Table of Contents
1. [Overview](#overview)
2. [Architecture](#architecture)
3. [CLI Commands](#cli-commands)
4. [Python Scanner](#python-scanner)
5. [Data Schema](#data-schema)
6. [Next.js Portfolio](#nextjs-portfolio)
7. [Workflows](#workflows)
8. [Installation](#installation)

---

## Overview

**Portfolio-OPs** is a command-line tool that automates portfolio creation and maintenance by:
- Scanning your Desktop for code projects
- Extracting metadata, READMEs, and assets
- Generating structured JSON data
- Powering a Next.js portfolio website

### Design Philosophy
- **Zero Configuration:** Works out of the box
- **Smart Detection:** Automatically identifies project types
- **Markdown-First:** READMEs become your project descriptions
- **Git-Aware:** Tracks project activity and status
- **Incremental Updates:** Only processes changed projects

## CLI Commands

### Basic Usage

```bash
# Navigate to your Desktop
cd ~/Desktop

# First time setup
python3 portfolio.py init

# Scan all projects (full scan)
python3 portfolio.py generate

# Update only changed projects (fast)
python3 portfolio.py update

# List all detected projects
python3 portfolio.py list

# Show specific project details
python3 portfolio.py show project-name

# Rebuild portfolio frontend
python3 portfolio.py build

# Clean cache and start fresh
python3 portfolio.py clean
```

### Advanced Commands

```bash

python3 portfolio.py generate --path ~/Projects

# Export to custom location
python3 portfolio.py generate --output ./my-portfolio-data

# Exclude certain directories

# Set scan depth
python3 portfolio.py generate --depth 3

# Generate with verbose output
python3 portfolio.py generate --verbose

# Preview without saving
python3 portfolio.py generate --dry-run

# Mark project as featured
python3 portfolio.py feature project-name

# Set project category
python3 portfolio.py categorize project-name "Web Development"

# Archive old project
python3 portfolio.py archive project-name
```

## Workflows

### First-Time Setup

```bash
# 1. Clone or create portfolio-ops
cd ~/Desktop
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/portfolio-ops.git
cd portfolio-ops

# 2. Install Python dependencies
pip3 install -r requirements.txt

# 3. Initialize
python3 portfolio.py init

# Output:
# ‚úì Created portfolio-data directory
# ‚úì Created config file
# ‚úì Ready to scan!
```

### Daily Workflow

```bash
# Morning: Work on projects
cd ~/Desktop/my-new-project
# ... code, commit, push ...

# Afternoon: Update portfolio
cd ~/Desktop
python3 portfolio.py update

# Output:
# Scanning ~/Desktop...
# ‚úì Found 3 new projects
# ‚úì Updated 2 existing projects
# ‚úì Exported to portfolio-data/projects.json
# ‚úì Copied 5 screenshots
# 
# Summary:
#   Total Projects: 15
#   Featured: 5
#   Categories: Web (8), Mobile (3), CLI (4)

# If you have the Next.js dev server running, it auto-reloads!
```

### Publishing Workflow

```bash
# 1. Scan projects
python3 portfolio.py generate

# 2. Navigate to portfolio website
cd ~/Desktop/portfolio-website

# 3. Copy data (or use symlink)
cp -r ../portfolio-data ./public/

# 4. Build and deploy
npm run build
vercel deploy --prod

# Done! Portfolio live at: https://yourname.vercel.app
```

### Incremental Update Logic

```python
# portfolio.py update command does:

1. Load cache.json
2. For each project directory:
   - Check if it exists in cache
   - Compare last modified timestamp
   - If unchanged ‚Üí Skip (fast!)
   - If changed ‚Üí Re-scan metadata
   - If new ‚Üí Full scan
3. Only process changed projects
4. Update cache.json
5. Export new projects.json

# Result: Update takes 2-5 seconds instead of 30+ seconds
```

## Configuration

```yaml
scanner:

  max_depth: 3

  default_category: "Uncategorized"
  
  visibility_rules:
    - pattern: "test-*"
      visibility: hidden
    - pattern: "draft-*"
      visibility: draft
```

---

## Best Practices

### Project Organization

1. **README Guidelines**: Every project should have a README.md with:
   - Project description
   - Screenshots section
   - Tech stack
   - Features list

2. **Screenshots**: Place in `screenshots/` or `docs/images/`

3. **Git Commits**: Regular commits improve "last updated" display

### Portfolio Curation

```bash
# Mark best projects as featured
python3 portfolio.py feature awesome-project

# Set categories for organization
python3 portfolio.py categorize web-app "Web Development"

# Hide incomplete projects
python3 portfolio.py hide draft-project
```

### Performance Tips

1. Use `update` instead of `generate` for daily scans
2. Keep screenshot sizes under 2MB
3. Use `.portfolioignore` file to skip certain directories
4. Run `clean` monthly to remove stale cache

---

## Future Enhancements

- **Watch Mode**: Auto-update on file changes
- **GitHub Integration**: Pull stars, forks, issues count
- **AI Descriptions**: Generate descriptions if README missing
- **Screenshot Capture**: Auto-screenshot web apps
- **Analytics**: Track which projects get most views
- **Blog Integration**: Pull dev.to or Medium articles

---

## Troubleshooting

### Scanner Issues

**Problem**: Projects not detected
```bash
# Check if directory has project markers
python3 portfolio.py validate ~/Desktop/project-name

# Increase scan depth
python3 portfolio.py generate --depth 5
```

**Problem**: Slow scans
```bash
# Use update instead
python3 portfolio.py update

# Or ignore large directories
python3 portfolio.py generate --ignore node_modules,venv
```

### Next.js Issues

**Problem**: Images not loading
- Ensure assets copied to `public/portfolio-data/assets/`
- Check Next.js `next.config.js` allows external images

**Problem**: Markdown not rendering
- Verify `projects.json` has full markdown content
- Check ReactMarkdown configuration

---

## Support

For issues, suggestions, or contributions:
- GitHub: https://github.com/yourusername/portfolio-ops
- Email: your@email.com

---

**Happy Portfolio Building! üöÄ**

readme.content:
# Planspace Feature ‚Äì Technical Documentation

## Overview

The Planspace feature is inspired by Google Keep/Notion and allows users to create, manage, and work on multiple betting prediction slips. Each slip acts as a digital workspace for planning bets, adding matches, and tracking predictions.

---

## Main Components & Files

### 1. `app/planspace/page.jsx` (PlanSpacePage)
- **Purpose:** Main dashboard for all prediction slips.
- **Functionality:**
  - Displays all created slips as cards.
  - Prominent "+ Create Prediction Slip" button opens a modal form.
  - Manages slips state and persists slips to `localStorage`.
  - Each slip card has a "cook" icon to open the slip in detail view.

### 2. `components/PredictionSlipForm.jsx`
- **Purpose:** Modal form for creating a new prediction slip.
- **Inputs:**
  - Space Name (slip name)
  - Stake
  - Target Odds
  - (Auto-calculates expected win)
- **On submit:** Calls parent handler to add the slip to state and localStorage.

### 3. `components/PredictionSlipCard.jsx`
- **Purpose:** Card UI for displaying a single prediction slip in the dashboard.
- **Displays:**
  - Slip name, stake, target odds, expected win
  - List of matches added to the slip
  - "Cook" icon button to open the slip detail page

### 4. `app/planspace/[slipId]/page.jsx` (Slip Detail Page)
- **Purpose:** Dedicated workspace for a single prediction slip.
- **Functionality:**
  - Loads the slip by ID from `localStorage`
  - Displays slip details and matches
  - Allows adding matches to the slip using the `UpcomingMatches` component
  - Updates slip in state and `localStorage` when matches are added

### 5. `components/UpcomingMatches.jsx`
- **Purpose:** Displays a list of upcoming matches with an "Add to [Slip Name]" button for each.
- **Props:**
  - `matches`: Array of match objects to display
  - `onAdd`: Callback when a match is added to the slip
  - `slipName`: Name of the slip for button labeling

---

## Data Flow & Persistence
- All slips are stored in React state and persisted to `localStorage` under the key `planspace_slips`.
- When a slip is created or updated (e.g., matches added), the change is reflected in both state and `localStorage`.
- The slip detail page loads the slip by ID from `localStorage` for direct editing.

---

## User Flow
1. User lands on `/planspace` and sees all slips as cards.
2. User clicks "+ Create Prediction Slip" to open the form and create a new slip.
3. Each slip card shows summary info and a "cook" icon to open the slip detail page.
4. In the slip detail page, the user can add matches from the upcoming matches list.
5. All changes are saved to `localStorage` for persistence.

---

## Extensibility
- The architecture supports adding more features, such as editing slip details, removing matches, or integrating real match data APIs.
- The `UpcomingMatches` component can be reused or extended for filtering, searching, or advanced match selection.

---

## Technical Notes
- Uses React state and hooks for UI interactivity.
- Uses Next.js routing for navigation between dashboard and slip detail pages.
- Uses `localStorage` for persistence across page reloads.
- All components are styled with utility classes (e.g., Tailwind CSS) for a modern look.

# 
### ‚úÖ What We've Built

1. **Database Schema Updates**:
   - Added `ResumeProjects` table with resume-specific fields (description, role, technologies, achievements, start/end dates, priority, etc.)
   - Updated database schema version to 6
   - Added migration strategy for the new table

2. **Backend Services**:
   - Added resume methods to `FrameworkDetectionService` (addToResume, getResumeProjects, removeFromResume, updateResumeProject)
   - Added corresponding database methods in `AppDatabase`

3. **UI Components**:
   - **ResumeView**: Full-featured resume project management with expandable cards and editing capabilities
   - **ResumeScreen**: Dedicated resume builder screen with export/preview actions
   - **ResumeScreenWrapper**: Database integration wrapper

4. **Navigation Updates**:
   - Added "Add to Resume" button to project cards
   - Added Resume tab to Projects screen (4 tabs total: Projects, Portfolio, Resume, Timeline)
   - Added Resume navigation item to sidebar
   - Updated routing in main app

5. **Enhanced Functionality**:
   - Resume projects can be edited with detailed information (role, achievements, dates, etc.)
   - Priority-based ordering for resume projects
   - Current project indicators
   - Rich editing dialog with date pickers and form fields

### üéØ Current UI Layout Structure

Your app now has this navigation structure:

```
Sidebar Navigation:

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Desktop

‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Portfolio (list view of portfolio projects)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Resume (list view of resume projects with editing)
```

## üí° UI Layout Suggestions

### 1. **Sidebar Navigation Improvements**
Since you removed the Desktop item, consider:
- **Consolidate Projects & Resume**: The Projects screen already has a Resume tab, so the dedicated Resume screen might be redundant
- **Alternative**: Keep the dedicated Resume screen for advanced editing and use the Projects tab for quick management

### 2. **Projects Screen Tab Organization**
Current: Projects ‚Üí Portfolio ‚Üí Resume ‚Üí Timeline
Suggested: Projects ‚Üí Portfolio ‚Üí Resume ‚Üí Timeline
- This works well! The Resume tab provides quick access within the project context

### 3. **Resume View Enhancements**
The `ResumeView` includes:
- ‚úÖ Expandable cards for detailed project info
- ‚úÖ Edit dialog with comprehensive form fields
- ‚úÖ Priority ordering
- ‚úÖ Current project indicators

### 4. **Future UI Improvements**
Consider adding:
- **Drag & Drop Reordering**: For resume project priority
- **Resume Templates**: Different layout options
- **Export Options**: PDF, Markdown, JSON formats
- **Preview Mode**: Live resume preview

### 5. **Layout Consistency**
Your current layout with the sidebar + main content area is clean and follows good UX patterns. The tabbed interface in the Projects screen provides good organization without overwhelming the user.

## üöÄ Next Steps

Once you test the app, you might want to:

1. **Test the "Add to Resume" functionality** from the Projects grid
2. **Verify the Resume tab** in the Projects screen works correctly
3. **Test the dedicated Resume screen** navigation
4. **Check that editing resume projects** works as expected
5. **Verify database migrations** run correctly

The implementation should give you a solid foundation for managing both portfolio and resume projects with rich editing capabilities. Let me know how the testing goes and if you encounter any issues!

# dev_brief

To create a simple and valuable Flutter app with SQLite for developers to manage their local projects, you need to focus on delivering the most essential information and designing an intuitive first screen. Since the app launches automatically when the laptop or desktop starts and operates locally, it should provide a quick, actionable overview of all local projects and their statuses. Below, I‚Äôll outline the key information to prioritize and how to structure the UI for the first screen to maximize its usefulness.

### Information to Prioritize
For the app to be valuable, it should focus on the following pieces of information, which are critical for developers to manage their projects effectively:

- **Project Name**: This is the primary identifier for each project, making it easy for the developer to recognize their work at a glance.
- **Status**: Clearly indicate whether a project is **unfinished**, **dead**, or **finished**. This helps the developer quickly assess which projects require attention or can be ignored.
- **Last Launched Date**: Show the date when the project was last opened through the app. This provides insight into recent activity and helps prioritize tasks, reflecting the developer‚Äôs interaction with the project via this tool.
- **Project Path**: Store the file system path to the project directory. This is essential for enabling the "Launch in VS Code" feature, allowing seamless access to the project.

These elements ensure the app delivers concise, actionable data without overwhelming the user.

### UI Structure for the First Screen
The first screen should be clean, intuitive, and focused on providing an immediate overview of projects, with quick access to key actions for unfinished projects. Here‚Äôs how it should be structured:

#### **App Bar**
- **Title**: Display the app name (e.g., "Project Manager") to provide context.
- **Settings Icon**: Include an icon (e.g., a gear) on the right side that opens a settings page. This allows the developer to configure options like the VS Code executable path or app preferences.

#### **Filter Tabs**
- Provide a row of filter tabs below the app bar to sort projects by status:
  - **All**: Shows every project regardless of status.
  - **Unfinished**: Displays only unfinished projects (set as the default view).
  - **Dead**: Shows projects marked as dead.
  - **Finished**: Lists completed projects.
- **Default View**: Set to "Unfinished" since these are the projects most likely needing attention when the developer starts their device. This focuses the app on actionable tasks right away.

#### **Project Cards**
- Use a scrollable list of cards to display projects based on the selected filter. Each card should include:
  - **Project Name**: In bold text for emphasis and easy scanning.
  - **Status**: Displayed with color-coding for quick recognition:
    - Yellow for **unfinished** (indicating active work).
    - Red for **dead** (signaling abandonment).
    - Green for **finished** (showing completion).
  - **Last Launched Date**: Shown as "Last Launched: [date]" to indicate the last time the project was opened via the app.
  - **Actions for Unfinished Projects**:
    - **"Launch in VS Code" Button**: A button that opens the project directory in VS Code using the stored project path.
    - **Gravestone Icon**: A clickable icon (e.g., a tombstone) to mark the project as dead, updating its status in the database after a confirmation prompt.

#### **Optional Enhancements**
- **Search Bar**: Add a search field above the project list to let developers quickly find projects by name, enhancing usability for those with many projects.
- **Project Counters**: Display a count in the app bar or near the filter tabs (e.g., "Unfinished Projects: 5") to give an instant sense of workload.

### Why This Works
- **Prioritized Information**: The focus on project name, status, last launched date, and path ensures the developer gets the most relevant details without clutter. The "Last Launched" date, updated when a project is opened via the app, keeps the info practical and tied to app usage.
- **UI Design**: The app bar, filter tabs, and project cards create a structured, glanceable interface. Defaulting to unfinished projects aligns with the developer‚Äôs likely intent‚Äîstarting work‚Äîwhile color-coded statuses and action buttons make it fast and easy to act on projects.
- **Local Focus**: Since all operations are local, the SQLite database (with a simple table for id, name, status, path, and last_launched) and Flutter‚Äôs lightweight widgets ensure quick startup and responsiveness, fitting the autostart requirement.

This approach delivers a valuable tool that simplifies project management, keeps the developer focused, and integrates seamlessly into their workflow.

Here's a detailed breakdown of every function, prop, and data flow in your `PureForm` component:

---

### **Props**
1. **`onClose`**  
   - **Type**: Function  
   - **Purpose**: Called when the user clicks the close button (√ó) or "Proceed to Checkout".  
   - **Data Passed**: None (parent component handles closing logic).  

2. **`onAddToCart`**  
   - **Type**: Function  
   - **Purpose**: Called when adding valid products to the cart.  
   - **Data Passed**: Array of valid products (filtered to exclude empty entries).  
   - **Expected Parent Behavior**:  
     ```jsx
     const [cart, setCart] = useState([]);
     const handleAddToCart = (newProducts) => {
       setCart([...cart, ...newProducts]);
     };
     ```

---

### **State Variables**
1. **`products`**  
   - **Type**: Array of `{ name: string, brand: string, quantity: number }`  
   - **Purpose**: Tracks user input for each product row. Initialized with one empty row.  

2. **`isAdded`**  
   - **Type**: Boolean  
   - **Purpose**: Temporarily shows "Added to Cart!" feedback (resets after 2 seconds).  

3. **`cartCount`**  
   - **Type**: Number  
   - **Purpose**: Displays total items in the cart (sum of all quantities).  

4. **`searchResults`**  
   - **Type**: Array of products from `mockProducts`  
   - **Purpose**: Stores products matching the user's search query.  

5. **`showResults`**  
   - **Type**: Boolean  
   - **Purpose**: Toggles between the form view and search results view.  

---

### **Core Functions**
1. **`useEffect` (Auto-Focus)**  
   - **Trigger**: On component mount (`[]` dependency).  
   - **Action**: Focuses the first product name input field for immediate typing.  

2. **`handleChange(index, event)`**  
   - **Purpose**: Updates a product field (name, brand, or quantity) as the user types.  
   - **Logic**:  
     - For `quantity`, ensures the value is ‚â• 1.  
     - Creates a copy of `products` array, updates the specific field, and sets state.  

3. **`handleQuantityChange(index, amount)`**  
   - **Purpose**: Increments/decrements quantity via +/- buttons.  
   - **Logic**: Adjusts quantity while ensuring it never drops below 1.  

4. **`handleAddProduct()`**  
   - **Purpose**: Adds a new empty product row to the form.  

5. **`handleAddToCart()`**  
   - **Purpose**: Validates and submits products to the cart.  
   - **Logic**:  
     - Filters out empty/partial entries (requires both `name` and `brand`).  
     - Calls `onAddToCart(validProducts)` to notify the parent.  
     - Updates `cartCount` with the sum of quantities.  
     - Resets the form (keeps one empty row) and shows feedback.  

6. **`handleViewCart()`**  
   - **Purpose**: Searches `mockProducts` for matches against user input.  
   - **Logic**:  
     - Filters `mockProducts` where `name` or `brand` partially matches any form entry.  
     - Case-insensitive comparison.  
     - Sets results and switches to the results view.  

7. **`closeResults()`**  
   - **Purpose**: Returns to the form view from search results.  

8. **`toggleExpand()` / `precardExpand()`**  
   - **Purpose**: Controls UI expansion states (unused in current JSX but kept for future features).  

---

### **Search Results Logic**
- **Rendering**: When `showResults` is `true`, displays a grid of product cards.  
- **Product Card Actions**:  
  - **"Select" Button**: Auto-fills the first form row with the clicked product‚Äôs data and returns to the form.  
  - **Image Handling**: Falls back to a placeholder if `imageUrl` fails to load.  

---

### **UI Flow**
1. **Form Input** ‚Üí **Add to Cart**  
   - User fills product details ‚Üí clicks "Add to Cart" ‚Üí parent is notified ‚Üí form resets.  
2. **Form Input** ‚Üí **View Cart & Search**  
   - User enters partial names/brands ‚Üí clicks "View Cart" ‚Üí sees matching products ‚Üí can select one to auto-fill the form.  
3. **Checkout**  
   - Visible only if `cartCount > 0` ‚Üí triggers `onClose`.  

---

### **Key Features**
- **Validation**: Prevents adding empty/incomplete products.  
- **Persistence**: Cart count persists even when the form resets.  
- **Responsive Design**: Grid layout adapts to screen size (1‚Äì3 columns).  
- **Error Handling**: Image fallback, quantity safeguards.  

This component is designed for **speed** (minimal inputs, quick search) while ensuring **robustness** (validation, error handling). Integrate with your e-commerce backend via the `onAddToCart` and `onClose` props.

# üì¶ Quick Order E-commerce Widget ‚Äì Documentation

## üß© Overview

This project implements a **Quick Order Widget** designed for e-commerce websites to enable fast product ordering in **three steps or less**. The widget is built using **React** and **Tailwind CSS**, and is designed to **float at the bottom of the page**, providing a sleek and user-friendly experience for shoppers.

---

## üèóÔ∏è Component Structure

### 1. `QuickOrderForm`

**Purpose**: The central component that lets users quickly select from popular products, specify quantity and size, and add items to the cart.

**Key Features**:

* Appears as a floating rounded rectangle at the bottom center of the page.
* Toggleable height via **Expand/Minimize** icon.
* Step 1: Users are greeted with a call to action.
* Step 2: Users can select a default product, input quantity and size, and add to cart.

**Props**:

* `onAddToCart`: Function to send selected product details to the cart or parent handler.

**States**:

* `isExpanded`: Boolean for expanded/minimized height.
* `showForm`: Toggle between welcome view and form.
* `selectedItem`: The product selected by user.
* `quantity`: Quantity number input.
* `size`: Size input (e.g. 1kg, 2L).

**Icons Used**:

* `Zap`: Speed symbol for shopping.
* `Expand` / `Minimize`: Toggles height of widget.
* `ShoppingCart`: Indicates shopping-related actions.

---

### 2. `ViewCartButton`

**Purpose**: Allows user to quickly access the current cart.

**Props**:

* `onViewCart`: Function to display cart summary.

**UI**:

* A small button styled with Tailwind, showing an eye icon and ‚ÄúView Cart‚Äù.

---

### 3. `ProceedToCheckout`

**Purpose**: After items are added to cart, user can proceed to checkout or add more.

**Props**:

* `onCheckout`: Action to proceed to checkout.
* `onAddMore`: Action to go back and add more products.

---

### 4. `CartSummary`

**Purpose**: Displays a summary of all items in the cart.

**Props**:

* `cartItems`: Array of product objects added to cart.
* `onCheckout`: Function triggered when user chooses to checkout.

**Structure**:

* Lists each item with its quantity, name, size, and brand.
* ‚ÄúCheckout Now‚Äù button for final submission.

---

## üîó Parent Component Structure (Suggested)

A parent component can manage the entire widget state using something like a `switch` statement or conditional rendering.

```jsx
const [view, setView] = useState("quickOrder"); // other values: 'cartSummary', 'checkout'

switch (view) {
  case "quickOrder":
    return <QuickOrderForm onAddToCart={handleAddToCart} />;
  case "cartSummary":
    return <CartSummary cartItems={cartItems} onCheckout={handleCheckout} />;
  default:
    return <ProceedToCheckout onCheckout={handleCheckout} onAddMore={() => setView("quickOrder")} />;
}
```

---

## üõ†Ô∏è Technologies Used

* **React**: Component-based UI development
* **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework
* **Lucide-react**: Icon library for beautiful SVG icons
* **JSX & Functional Components**: Modern React practices

---

## üí° Suggested Enhancements

* üîÑ Persist cart items in local storage or global state (e.g. Redux).
* üì≤ Make the widget mobile-responsive.
* ‚úÖ Add input validation for size and quantity.
* üõçÔ∏è Allow users to input custom products (not just default list).

readme.content:
Thanks ‚Äî I‚Äôve fully reviewed the README you uploaded.

You're using the modern Shopify Node app template (based on Express + Vite + React + React Router), and here's what that changes for our plan:

---

## ‚úÖ Key Takeaways from the README

1. This is not "backendless" ‚Äî it still uses an Express backend under the hood (with OAuth, Admin API access, sessions, and webhooks).
2. You don't need to manually build routes like /server/routes/api.js from scratch ‚Äî Shopify CLI already wires up a working Express server with session-aware Admin API access.
3. Your backend lives under the /web directory (e.g. /web/index.js, /web/middleware).
4. You don‚Äôt need to touch the frontend inside this repo since you‚Äôve already deployed your own widget on Vercel.
5. Shopify App Bridge and Admin API functionality is still present and supported.

So your original plan (OAuth, access token storage, and Admin API product access) is still correct ‚Äî we just need to align with the newer directory structure.

---

## ‚úÖ What You Should Do Next

Now that your Shopify Node app is working and installed on your test store:

### 1. Inject Your Widget into the Storefront via ScriptTag API

This part is still 100% valid.

We'll add code to the afterAuth lifecycle in your app backend to register a ScriptTag that loads your hosted widget.js (from Vercel) into the storefront.

We‚Äôll do this inside:

üìÅ web/index.js ‚Üí in the afterAuth section

I‚Äôll walk you through that once you confirm you're ready.

‚Äî

### 2. Add Backend API Routes for Your Widget to Use

Your widget (on the storefront) will fetch:

* Product data via GET /api/products
* Checkout links via POST /api/checkout

We‚Äôll define these two routes using the Express router in:

üìÅ web/index.js or in a new üìÅ web/routes/widget.js file (I‚Äôll help set that up cleanly)

‚Äî

### 3. Secure the Routes with Session Validation

Each route will need to:

* Load the merchant session from the session store
* Use the stored access token to call the Shopify Admin or Storefront API

This logic is already handled via Shopify's SDK and middleware. We‚Äôll just reuse it.

‚Äî

‚úÖ Summary:

* You‚Äôre not backendless ‚Äî you just don‚Äôt need to manually configure Koa or separate folders anymore
* The app is Express + Vite + React under a monorepo structure (web/ folder holds everything)
* Your own storefront widget hosted on Vercel is a separate concern ‚Äî but it will now fetch from this app‚Äôs backend

‚Äî

üß≠ Next Step:

Shall I help you write the ScriptTag injection code inside web/index.js now? That‚Äôs the most direct next move.

readme.content:
# Shopify App Template - Remix

This is a template for building a [Shopify app](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started) using the [Remix](https://remix.run) framework.

Rather than cloning this repo, you can use your preferred package manager and the Shopify CLI with [these steps](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started/create).

Visit the [`shopify.dev` documentation](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/shopify-app-remix) for more details on the Remix app package.

## Quick start

### Prerequisites

Before you begin, you'll need the following:

1. **Node.js**: [Download and install](https://nodejs.org/en/download/) it if you haven't already.
2. **Shopify Partner Account**: [Create an account](https://partners.shopify.com/signup) if you don't have one.
3. **Test Store**: Set up either a [development store](https://help.shopify.com/en/partners/dashboard/development-stores#create-a-development-store) or a [Shopify Plus sandbox store](https://help.shopify.com/en/partners/dashboard/managing-stores/plus-sandbox-store) for testing your app.

### Setup

If you used the CLI to create the template, you can skip this section.

Using yarn:

```shell
yarn install
```

Using npm:

```shell
npm install
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
pnpm install
```

### Local Development

Using yarn:

```shell
yarn dev
```

Using npm:

```shell
npm run dev
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
pnpm run dev
```

Press P to open the URL to your app. Once you click install, you can start development.

Local development is powered by [the Shopify CLI](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/cli). It logs into your partners account, connects to an app, provides environment variables, updates remote config, creates a tunnel and provides commands to generate extensions.

### Authenticating and querying data

To authenticate and query data you can use the `shopify` const that is exported from `/app/shopify.server.js`:

```js
export async function loader({ request }) {
  const { admin } = await shopify.authenticate.admin(request);

  const response = await admin.graphql(`
    {
      products(first: 25) {
        nodes {
          title
          description
        }
      }
    }`);

  const {
    data: {
      products: { nodes },
    },
  } = await response.json();

  return nodes;
}
```

This template comes preconfigured with examples of:

1. Setting up your Shopify app in [/app/shopify.server.ts](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-template-remix/blob/main/app/shopify.server.ts)
2. Querying data using Graphql. Please see: [/app/routes/app.\_index.tsx](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-template-remix/blob/main/app/routes/app._index.tsx).
3. Responding to webhooks in individual files such as [/app/routes/webhooks.app.uninstalled.tsx](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-template-remix/blob/main/app/routes/webhooks.app.uninstalled.tsx) and [/app/routes/webhooks.app.scopes_update.tsx](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-template-remix/blob/main/app/routes/webhooks.app.scopes_update.tsx)

Please read the [documentation for @shopify/shopify-app-remix](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@shopify/shopify-app-remix#authenticating-admin-requests) to understand what other API's are available.

## Deployment

### Application Storage

This template uses [Prisma](https://www.prisma.io/) to store session data, by default using an [SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/index.html) database.
The database is defined as a Prisma schema in `prisma/schema.prisma`.

This use of SQLite works in production if your app runs as a single instance.
The database that works best for you depends on the data your app needs and how it is queried.
You can run your database of choice on a server yourself or host it with a SaaS company.
Here's a short list of databases providers that provide a free tier to get started:

| Database   | Type             | Hosters                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ---------- | ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| MySQL      | SQL              | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/products/managed-databases-mysql), [Planet Scale](https://planetscale.com/), [Amazon Aurora](https://aws.amazon.com/rds/aurora/), [Google Cloud SQL](https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql) |
| PostgreSQL | SQL              | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/products/managed-databases-postgresql), [Amazon Aurora](https://aws.amazon.com/rds/aurora/), [Google Cloud SQL](https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/postgres)                                   |
| Redis      | Key-value        | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/products/managed-databases-redis), [Amazon MemoryDB](https://aws.amazon.com/memorydb/)                                                                                                        |
| MongoDB    | NoSQL / Document | [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com/products/managed-databases-mongodb), [MongoDB Atlas](https://www.mongodb.com/atlas/database)                                                                                                  |

To use one of these, you can use a different [datasource provider](https://www.prisma.io/docs/reference/api-reference/prisma-schema-reference#datasource) in your `schema.prisma` file, or a different [SessionStorage adapter package](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-api-js/blob/main/packages/shopify-api/docs/guides/session-storage.md).

### Build

Remix handles building the app for you, by running the command below with the package manager of your choice:

Using yarn:

```shell
yarn build
```

Using npm:

```shell
npm run build
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
pnpm run build
```

## Hosting

When you're ready to set up your app in production, you can follow [our deployment documentation](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/deployment/web) to host your app on a cloud provider like [Heroku](https://www.heroku.com/) or [Fly.io](https://fly.io/).

When you reach the step for [setting up environment variables](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/deployment/web#set-env-vars), you also need to set the variable `NODE_ENV=production`.

### Hosting on Vercel

Using the Vercel Preset is recommended when hosting your Shopify Remix app on Vercel. You'll also want to ensure imports that would normally come from `@remix-run/node` are imported from `@vercel/remix` instead. Learn more about hosting Remix apps on Vercel [here](https://vercel.com/docs/frameworks/remix).

```diff
// vite.config.ts
import { vitePlugin as remix } from "@remix-run/dev";
import { defineConfig, type UserConfig } from "vite";
import tsconfigPaths from "vite-tsconfig-paths";
+ import { vercelPreset } from '@vercel/remix/vite';

installGlobals();

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [
    remix({
      ignoredRouteFiles: ["**/.*"],
+     presets: [vercelPreset()],
    }),
    tsconfigPaths(),
  ],
});
```

## Troubleshooting

### Database tables don't exist

If you get this error:

```
The table `main.Session` does not exist in the current database.
```

You need to create the database for Prisma. Run the `setup` script in `package.json` using your preferred package manager.

### Navigating/redirecting breaks an embedded app

Embedded Shopify apps must maintain the user session, which can be tricky inside an iFrame. To avoid issues:

1. Use `Link` from `@remix-run/react` or `@shopify/polaris`. Do not use `<a>`.
2. Use the `redirect` helper returned from `authenticate.admin`. Do not use `redirect` from `@remix-run/node`
3. Use `useSubmit` or `<Form/>` from `@remix-run/react`. Do not use a lowercase `<form/>`.

This only applies if your app is embedded, which it will be by default.

### Non Embedded

Shopify apps are best when they are embedded in the Shopify Admin, which is how this template is configured. If you have a reason to not embed your app please make the following changes:

1. Ensure `embedded = false` is set in [shopify.app.toml`](./shopify.app.toml). [Docs here](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/build/cli-for-apps/app-configuration#global).
2. Pass `isEmbeddedApp: false` to `shopifyApp()` in `./app/shopify.server.js|ts`.
3. Change the `isEmbeddedApp` prop to `isEmbeddedApp={false}` for the `AppProvider` in `/app/routes/app.jsx|tsx`.
4. Remove the `@shopify/app-bridge-react` dependency from [package.json](./package.json) and `vite.config.ts|js`.
5. Remove anything imported from `@shopify/app-bridge-react`.  For example: `NavMenu`, `TitleBar` and `useAppBridge`.

### OAuth goes into a loop when I change my app's scopes

If you change your app's scopes and authentication goes into a loop and fails with a message from Shopify that it tried too many times, you might have forgotten to update your scopes with Shopify.
To do that, you can run the `deploy` CLI command.

Using yarn:

```shell
yarn deploy
```

Using npm:

```shell
npm run deploy
```

Using pnpm:

```shell
pnpm run deploy
```

### My shop-specific webhook subscriptions aren't updated

If you are registering webhooks in the `afterAuth` hook, using `shopify.registerWebhooks`, you may find that your subscriptions aren't being updated.  

Instead of using the `afterAuth` hook, the recommended approach is to declare app-specific webhooks in the `shopify.app.toml` file.  This approach is easier since Shopify will automatically update changes to webhook subscriptions every time you run `deploy` (e.g: `npm run deploy`).  Please read these guides to understand more:

1. [app-specific vs shop-specific webhooks](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/build/webhooks/subscribe#app-specific-subscriptions)
2. [Create a subscription tutorial](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/build/webhooks/subscribe/get-started?framework=remix&deliveryMethod=https)

If you do need shop-specific webhooks, please keep in mind that the package calls `afterAuth` in 2 scenarios:

- After installing the app
- When an access token expires

During normal development, the app won't need to re-authenticate most of the time, so shop-specific subscriptions aren't updated. To force your app to update the subscriptions, you can uninstall and reinstall it in your development store. That will force the OAuth process and call the `afterAuth` hook.

### Admin created webhook failing HMAC validation

Webhooks subscriptions created in the [Shopify admin](https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/orders/notifications/webhooks) will fail HMAC validation. This is because the webhook payload is not signed with your app's secret key.  There are 2 solutions:

1. Use [app-specific webhooks](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/build/webhooks/subscribe#app-specific-subscriptions) defined in your toml file instead (recommended)
2. Create [webhook subscriptions](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/shopify-app-remix/v1/guide-webhooks) using the `shopifyApp` object.

Test your webhooks with the [Shopify CLI](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/cli/commands#webhook-trigger) or by triggering events manually in the Shopify admin(e.g. Updating the product title to trigger a `PRODUCTS_UPDATE`).

### Incorrect GraphQL Hints

By default the [graphql.vscode-graphql](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GraphQL.vscode-graphql) extension for VS Code will assume that GraphQL queries or mutations are for the [Shopify Admin API](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/admin). This is a sensible default, but it may not be true if:

1. You use another Shopify API such as the storefront API.
2. You use a third party GraphQL API.

in this situation, please update the [.graphqlrc.ts](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-template-remix/blob/main/.graphqlrc.ts) config.

### First parameter has member 'readable' that is not a ReadableStream.

See [hosting on Vercel](#hosting-on-vercel).

### Admin object undefined on webhook events triggered by the CLI

When you trigger a webhook event using the Shopify CLI, the `admin` object will be `undefined`. This is because the CLI triggers an event with a valid, but non-existent, shop. The `admin` object is only available when the webhook is triggered by a shop that has installed the app.

Webhooks triggered by the CLI are intended for initial experimentation testing of your webhook configuration. For more information on how to test your webhooks, see the [Shopify CLI documentation](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/cli/commands#webhook-trigger).

### Using Defer & await for streaming responses

To test [streaming using defer/await](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/guides/streaming) during local development you'll need to use the Shopify CLI slightly differently:

1. First setup ngrok: https://ngrok.com/product/secure-tunnels
2. Create an ngrok tunnel on port 8080: `ngrok http 8080`.
3. Copy the forwarding address. This should be something like: `https://f355-2607-fea8-bb5c-8700-7972-d2b5-3f2b-94ab.ngrok-free.app`
4. In a separate terminal run `yarn shopify app dev --tunnel-url=TUNNEL_URL:8080` replacing `TUNNEL_URL` for the address you copied in step 3.

By default the CLI uses a cloudflare tunnel. Unfortunately it cloudflare tunnels wait for the Response stream to finish, then sends one chunk.

This will not affect production, since tunnels are only for local development.

### Using MongoDB and Prisma

By default this template uses SQLlite as the database. It is recommended to move to a persisted database for production. If you choose to use MongoDB, you will need to make some modifications to the schema and prisma configuration. For more information please see the [Prisma MongoDB documentation](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/overview/databases/mongodb).

Alternatively you can use a MongDB database directly with the [MongoDB session storage adapter](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-js/tree/main/packages/apps/session-storage/shopify-app-session-storage-mongodb).

#### Mapping the id field

In MongoDB, an ID must be a single field that defines an @id attribute and a @map("\_id") attribute.
The prisma adapter expects the ID field to be the ID of the session, and not the \_id field of the document.

To make this work you can add a new field to the schema that maps the \_id field to the id field. For more information see the [Prisma documentation](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/prisma-schema/data-model/models#defining-an-id-field)

```prisma
model Session {
  session_id  String    @id @default(auto()) @map("_id") @db.ObjectId
  id          String    @unique
...
}
```

#### Error: The "mongodb" provider is not supported with this command

MongoDB does not support the [prisma migrate](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/prisma-migrate/understanding-prisma-migrate/overview) command. Instead, you can use the [prisma db push](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/reference/prisma-cli-reference#db-push) command and update the `shopify.web.toml` file with the following commands. If you are using MongoDB please see the [Prisma documentation](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/overview/databases/mongodb) for more information.

```toml
[commands]
predev = "npx prisma generate && npx prisma db push"
dev = "npm exec remix vite:dev"
```

#### Prisma needs to perform transactions, which requires your mongodb server to be run as a replica set

See the [Prisma documentation](https://www.prisma.io/docs/getting-started/setup-prisma/start-from-scratch/mongodb/connect-your-database-node-mongodb) for connecting to a MongoDB database.

### I want to use Polaris v13.0.0 or higher

Currently, this template is set up to work on node v18.20 or higher. However, `@shopify/polaris` is limited to v12 because v13 can only run on node v20+.

You don't have to make any changes to the code in order to be able to upgrade Polaris to v13, but you'll need to do the following:

- Upgrade your node version to v20.10 or higher.
- Update your `Dockerfile` to pull `FROM node:20-alpine` instead of `node:18-alpine`

### "nbf" claim timestamp check failed

This error will occur of the `nbf` claim timestamp check failed. This is because the JWT token is expired.
If you  are consistently getting this error, it could be that the clock on your machine is not in sync with the server.

To fix this ensure you have enabled `Set time and date automatically` in the `Date and Time` settings on your computer.

## Benefits

Shopify apps are built on a variety of Shopify tools to create a great merchant experience.

<!-- TODO: Uncomment this after we've updated the docs -->
<!-- The [create an app](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started/create) tutorial in our developer documentation will guide you through creating a Shopify app using this template. -->

The Remix app template comes with the following out-of-the-box functionality:

- [OAuth](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-js/tree/main/packages/shopify-app-remix#authenticating-admin-requests): Installing the app and granting permissions
- [GraphQL Admin API](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-js/tree/main/packages/shopify-app-remix#using-the-shopify-admin-graphql-api): Querying or mutating Shopify admin data
- [Webhooks](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-js/tree/main/packages/shopify-app-remix#authenticating-webhook-requests): Callbacks sent by Shopify when certain events occur
- [AppBridge](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/app-bridge): This template uses the next generation of the Shopify App Bridge library which works in unison with previous versions.
- [Polaris](https://polaris.shopify.com/): Design system that enables apps to create Shopify-like experiences

## Tech Stack

This template uses [Remix](https://remix.run). The following Shopify tools are also included to ease app development:

- [Shopify App Remix](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/shopify-app-remix) provides authentication and methods for interacting with Shopify APIs.
- [Shopify App Bridge](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/app-bridge) allows your app to seamlessly integrate your app within Shopify's Admin.
- [Polaris React](https://polaris.shopify.com/) is a powerful design system and component library that helps developers build high quality, consistent experiences for Shopify merchants.
- [Webhooks](https://github.com/Shopify/shopify-app-js/tree/main/packages/shopify-app-remix#authenticating-webhook-requests): Callbacks sent by Shopify when certain events occur
- [Polaris](https://polaris.shopify.com/): Design system that enables apps to create Shopify-like experiences

## Resources

- [Remix Docs](https://remix.run/docs/en/v1)
- [Shopify App Remix](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/shopify-app-remix)
- [Introduction to Shopify apps](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/getting-started)
- [App authentication](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/auth)
- [Shopify CLI](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/tools/cli)
- [App extensions](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/app-extensions/list)
- [Shopify Functions](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/functions)
- [Getting started with internationalizing your app](https://shopify.dev/docs/apps/best-practices/internationalization/getting-started)

# **Quick Cart Backend: Structured Architecture Documentation**  

## **üìå Overview**  
This documentation explains the **improved folder structure** for your Quick Cart Shopify backend, its **advantages over simpler structures**, and a **detailed breakdown of each file's purpose** for better maintainability and scalability.  

---

## **üîç Comparison: Old vs. New Structure**  

### **Old Structure (Initial)**
```
quick-cart-backend/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ routes/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ auth.js
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ shopify.js
```
‚úÖ **Pros:**  
- Simple for small projects  
- Quick to set up  

‚ùå **Cons:**  
- **No separation of concerns** (routes handle business logic directly)  
- **Hard to scale** (adding new features becomes messy)  
- **No proper error handling** (global errors are unmanaged)  
- **No database layer** (cookies used for session storage)  
- **Difficult to test** (tight coupling between routes and logic)  

---

### **New Structure (Improved)**
```
quick-cart-backend/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config/          # App configurations
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ controllers/     # HTTP request handlers
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ routes/          # API route definitions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ services/        # Business logic
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ models/          # Database schemas
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ middlewares/     # Request processors
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/           # Helper functions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/           # Unit & integration tests
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ server.js        # Entry point
```
‚úÖ **Advantages:**  
1. **Modular & Maintainable**  
   - Each component has a single responsibility.  
   - Easier to debug and extend.  

2. **Better Error Handling**  
   - Dedicated error middleware for consistent responses.  

3. **Scalable**  
   - New features can be added without breaking existing code.  

4. **Testable**  
   - Business logic is isolated in `services/`, making unit testing easier.  

5. **Production-Ready**  
   - Supports logging, rate limiting, and security best practices.  

6. **Team-Friendly**  
   - Clear structure helps multiple developers collaborate.  

---

## **üìÇ Detailed File Breakdown**  

### **1. `config/` ‚Äì App Configuration**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `index.js` | Centralized app settings (port, env vars) |
| `shopify.js` | Shopify API keys, scopes, and versioning |
| `database.js` | DB connection (MongoDB/PostgreSQL) |

**Example (`config/index.js`):**
```javascript
module.exports = {
  PORT: process.env.PORT || 3000,
  NODE_ENV: process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development',
  SHOPIFY_API_VERSION: '2023-07'
};
```

---

### **2. `controllers/` ‚Äì HTTP Request Handlers**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `auth.controller.js` | Handles OAuth install & callback |
| `products.controller.js` | Manages product search logic |
| `cart.controller.js` | Handles cart operations (add/view) |
| `webhooks.controller.js` | Processes Shopify webhooks |

**Example (`products.controller.js`):**
```javascript
const ProductService = require('../services/search.service');

exports.bulkSearch = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const results = await ProductService.search(req.query.terms);
    res.json(results);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: "Search failed" });
  }
};
```

---

### **3. `routes/` ‚Äì API Endpoints**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `index.js` | Main router combining all routes |
| `auth.routes.js` | `/shopify/install`, `/shopify/callback` |
| `api/products.routes.js` | `/api/products/search` |
| `api/cart.routes.js` | `/api/cart/add`, `/api/cart` |

**Example (`api/products.routes.js`):**
```javascript
const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();
const { bulkSearch } = require('../../controllers/products.controller');
const { verifyShopifySession } = require('../../middlewares/shopify.middleware');

router.get('/search', verifyShopifySession, bulkSearch);
module.exports = router;
```

---

### **4. `services/` ‚Äì Business Logic**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `shopify.service.js` | Shopify API wrapper (search, fetch products) |
| `cart.service.js` | Cart operations (add, retrieve) |
| `search.service.js` | Bulk product search logic |
| `session.service.js` | Manages merchant sessions |

**Example (`search.service.js`):**
```javascript
const axios = require('axios');

class SearchService {
  static async search(shop, accessToken, terms) {
    const results = await Promise.all(
      terms.map(term => axios.get(`https://${shop}/admin/products.json`, {
        headers: { 'X-Shopify-Access-Token': accessToken },
        params: { title: term }
      }))
    );
    return formatResults(results);
  }
}

module.exports = SearchService;
```

---

### **5. `models/` ‚Äì Database Schemas**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `Session.model.js` | Stores Shopify OAuth sessions |
| `Merchant.model.js` | Merchant-specific settings |
| `Cache.model.js` | Caches frequent searches |

**Example (`Session.model.js`):**
```javascript
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const SessionSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  shop: { type: String, required: true, unique: true },
  accessToken: { type: String, required: true },
  expiresAt: { type: Date, default: () => new Date(Date.now() + 30 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000) } // 30 days
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('Session', SessionSchema);
```

---

### **6. `middlewares/` ‚Äì Request Processors**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `auth.middleware.js` | Validates API keys |
| `shopify.middleware.js` | Checks Shopify session |
| `error.middleware.js` | Global error handler |
| `rateLimit.middleware.js` | Prevents API abuse |

**Example (`error.middleware.js`):**
```javascript
module.exports = (err, req, res, next) => {
  console.error(err.stack);
  res.status(500).json({
    error: "Internal Server Error",
    requestId: req.requestId // For tracking
  });
};
```

---

### **7. `utils/` ‚Äì Helper Functions**
| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `helpers.js` | Generic utilities (formatting, validation) |
| `logger.js` | Structured logging (Winston/Morgan) |
| `validator.js` | Input sanitization |

**Example (`logger.js`):**
```javascript
const winston = require('winston');

module.exports = winston.createLogger({
  level: 'info',
  format: winston.format.json(),
  transports: [new winston.transports.Console()]
});
```

---

## **üéØ Why This Structure Wins Over Flat Architectures**  
1. **Clean Code**  
   - No spaghetti code; logic is separated.  
2. **Easier Debugging**  
   - Errors are isolated to specific modules.  
3. **Better Testing**  
   - Services can be unit-tested independently.  
4. **Scalable**  
   - Adding new features doesn‚Äôt break old ones.  
5. **Team-Friendly**  
   - Multiple developers can work on different parts.  

---

## **üöÄ Next Steps**  
1. **Implement the new folder structure.**  
2. **Move existing code into the right modules.**  
3. **Set up a database (MongoDB/PostgreSQL).**  
4. **Add logging & error tracking.**  

Would you like me to provide **full example code** for any of these files? Or should we focus on implementing a specific part first? üõ†Ô∏è
headings: **üéØ Why This Structure Wins Over Flat Architectures**

# React + Vite
chat--- Redeers light account

# üßæ GanjiBoard - Technical Documentation

## üìã Project Overview

**GanjiBoard** is a web-based infinite canvas application for visual financial planning and collaborative budgeting. It combines the flexibility of a digital whiteboard with structured financial tracking capabilities.

**Current Version**: MVP v1.2
**Status**: In Development

---

## üéØ Core Value Proposition

Visual, collaborative financial planning that bridges the gap between spreadsheet precision and whiteboard flexibility.

---

## üèóÔ∏è Architecture & Tech Stack

### Frontend
- **Framework**: React 18 + Vite
- **Canvas Rendering**: React-Konva (Canvas-based)
- **Styling**: TailwindCSS
- **Icons**: React Icons (Fa*)
- **State Management**: React Hooks (useState, useEffect)

### Data Persistence
- **Primary Storage**: IndexedDB via localForage
- **Fallback**: localStorage (legacy)
- **File Operations**: JSON import/export

### Deployment
- **Platform**: Vercel/Netlify compatible
- **Build Tool**: Vite
- **Package Manager**: npm/yarn

---

## üß© Core Features Implemented

### 1. Infinite Canvas System
- **Konva-based Stage**: Infinite drag-and-drop canvas
- **Grid Background**: 40px grid with alignment guides
- **Responsive Design**: Adapts to window size

### 2. Multi-Type Card System
#### Budget Cards
- **Types**: Income (green), Expense (red), Savings (blue)
- **Properties**: Title, amount, category, frequency, notes
- **Visual**: Color-coded with type badges

#### Shopping List Cards
- **Properties**: Title, items array, total cost field
- **Interactivity**: Checkable items, strikethrough completion
- **Visual**: Purple theme with item checklist

#### Wishlist Cards
- **Properties**: Title, items with priorities (high/medium/low)
- **Visual**: Orange theme with priority indicators

### 3. Connection System
- **Arrow Connections**: Visual links between cards
- **Connection Tool**: Click-to-connect workflow
- **Data Model**: { id, fromId, toId } structure
- **Persistence**: Saved and restored with board state

### 4. Data Persistence
- **Auto-save**: Debounced 500ms save on state changes
- **IndexedDB Storage**: localForage wrapper for robust storage
- **Import/Export**: Full JSON board state backup/restore
- **Clear Functionality**: Complete board reset

### 5. Tool System
- **Toolbar**: Select, Connect, Draw, Text tools (UI ready)
- **Sidebar**: Card creation form with type-specific fields
- **Interaction Modes**: Drag, connect, create workflows

---

## üìä Data Models

### Card Object
```typescript
interface BaseCard {
  id: string;
  cardType: 'budget' | 'shopping' | 'wishlist';
  title: string;
  x: number;
  y: number;
}

interface BudgetCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'budget';
  type: 'income' | 'expense' | 'savings';
  amount: number | string;
  category: string;
  frequency: string;
  notes: string;
}

interface ShoppingCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'shopping';
  items: Array<{ name: string; checked: boolean }>;
  totalCost?: string;
}

interface WishlistCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'wishlist';
  items: Array<{ name: string; priority: 'high' | 'medium' | 'low' }>;
}
```

### Board State
```typescript
interface BoardState {
  cards: Array<BudgetCard | ShoppingCard | WishlistCard>;
  connections: Array<{
    id: string;
    fromId: string;
    toId: string;
  }>;
}
```

---

## üöÄ User Workflows

### 1. Board Creation
1. User opens app ‚Üí Loads last state from IndexedDB
2. Starts with empty canvas or previous work

### 2. Card Management
1. Click "+" button ‚Üí Opens sidebar
2. Select card type ‚Üí Shows type-specific form
3. Fill details ‚Üí Card appears on canvas
4. Drag to position ‚Üí Auto-saves position

### 3. Connection Creation
1. Select "Connect" tool ‚Üí Click first card ‚Üí Click second card
2. Arrow created ‚Üí Returns to Select tool
3. Auto-saves connection

### 4. Collaboration Preparation
1. Export board ‚Üí Downloads JSON file
2. Share file ‚Üí Others import into their GanjiBoard
3. Manual collaboration via file sharing

---

## üîß Technical Implementation Details

### Storage Service (`src/utils/storage.js`)
- **localForage Integration**: Async IndexedDB operations
- **Error Handling**: Graceful fallbacks and user feedback
- **Data Validation**: JSON schema validation on import
- **Performance**: Debounced saves to prevent UI blocking

### Component Structure
```
src/
```

# üßæ GanjiBoard - Technical Documentation

## üìã Project Overview

**GanjiBoard** is a web-based infinite canvas application for visual financial planning and collaborative budgeting. It combines the flexibility of a digital whiteboard with structured financial tracking capabilities.

**Current Version**: MVP v1.2
**Status**: In Development

---

## üéØ Core Value Proposition

Visual, collaborative financial planning that bridges the gap between spreadsheet precision and whiteboard flexibility.

---

## üèóÔ∏è Architecture & Tech Stack

### Frontend
- **Framework**: React 18 + Vite
- **Canvas Rendering**: React-Konva (Canvas-based)
- **Styling**: TailwindCSS
- **Icons**: React Icons (Fa*)
- **State Management**: React Hooks (useState, useEffect)

### Data Persistence
- **Primary Storage**: IndexedDB via localForage
- **Fallback**: localStorage (legacy)
- **File Operations**: JSON import/export

### Deployment
- **Platform**: Vercel/Netlify compatible
- **Build Tool**: Vite
- **Package Manager**: npm/yarn

---

## üß© Core Features Implemented

### 1. Infinite Canvas System
- **Konva-based Stage**: Infinite drag-and-drop canvas
- **Grid Background**: 40px grid with alignment guides
- **Responsive Design**: Adapts to window size

### 2. Multi-Type Card System
#### Budget Cards
- **Types**: Income (green), Expense (red), Savings (blue)
- **Properties**: Title, amount, category, frequency, notes
- **Visual**: Color-coded with type badges

#### Shopping List Cards
- **Properties**: Title, items array, total cost field
- **Interactivity**: Checkable items, strikethrough completion
- **Visual**: Purple theme with item checklist

#### Wishlist Cards
- **Properties**: Title, items with priorities (high/medium/low)
- **Visual**: Orange theme with priority indicators

### 3. Connection System
- **Arrow Connections**: Visual links between cards
- **Connection Tool**: Click-to-connect workflow
- **Data Model**: { id, fromId, toId } structure
- **Persistence**: Saved and restored with board state

### 4. Data Persistence
- **Auto-save**: Debounced 500ms save on state changes
- **IndexedDB Storage**: localForage wrapper for robust storage
- **Import/Export**: Full JSON board state backup/restore
- **Clear Functionality**: Complete board reset

### 5. Tool System
- **Toolbar**: Select, Connect, Draw, Text tools (UI ready)
- **Sidebar**: Card creation form with type-specific fields
- **Interaction Modes**: Drag, connect, create workflows

---

## üìä Data Models

### Card Object
```typescript
interface BaseCard {
  id: string;
  cardType: 'budget' | 'shopping' | 'wishlist';
  title: string;
  x: number;
  y: number;
}

interface BudgetCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'budget';
  type: 'income' | 'expense' | 'savings';
  amount: number | string;
  category: string;
  frequency: string;
  notes: string;
}

interface ShoppingCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'shopping';
  items: Array<{ name: string; checked: boolean }>;
  totalCost?: string;
}

interface WishlistCard extends BaseCard {
  cardType: 'wishlist';
  items: Array<{ name: string; priority: 'high' | 'medium' | 'low' }>;
}
```

### Board State
```typescript
interface BoardState {
  cards: Array<BudgetCard | ShoppingCard | WishlistCard>;
  connections: Array<{
    id: string;
    fromId: string;
    toId: string;
  }>;
}
```

---

## üöÄ User Workflows

### 1. Board Creation
1. User opens app ‚Üí Loads last state from IndexedDB
2. Starts with empty canvas or previous work

### 2. Card Management
1. Click "+" button ‚Üí Opens sidebar
2. Select card type ‚Üí Shows type-specific form
3. Fill details ‚Üí Card appears on canvas
4. Drag to position ‚Üí Auto-saves position

### 3. Connection Creation
1. Select "Connect" tool ‚Üí Click first card ‚Üí Click second card
2. Arrow created ‚Üí Returns to Select tool
3. Auto-saves connection

### 4. Collaboration Preparation
1. Export board ‚Üí Downloads JSON file
2. Share file ‚Üí Others import into their GanjiBoard
3. Manual collaboration via file sharing

---

## üîß Technical Implementation Details

### Storage Service (`src/utils/storage.js`)
- **localForage Integration**: Async IndexedDB operations
- **Error Handling**: Graceful fallbacks and user feedback
- **Data Validation**: JSON schema validation on import
- **Performance**: Debounced saves to prevent UI blocking

### Component Structure
```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App.jsx                 # Main application wrapper
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CanvasBoard.jsx         # Konva stage and layers

‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sidebar.jsx             # Card creation form
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ namebar.jsx             # Branding header
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ budgetCard.jsx          # Budget card renderer
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ shoplist.jsx            # Shopping list card renderer
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ wishlist.jsx            # Wishlist card renderer
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ connLayer.jsx           # Connection arrows renderer
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ storage.js              # Persistence layer
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ firebase.js                 # Future Firebase integration
```

# brief_bird
GPT NESHONYANGO ACCOUNT
To create a simple and valuable Flutter app with SQLite for developers to manage their local projects, you need to focus on delivering the most essential information and designing an intuitive first screen. Since the app launches automatically when the laptop or desktop starts and operates locally, it should provide a quick, actionable overview of all local projects and their statuses. Below, I‚Äôll outline the key information to prioritize and how to structure the UI for the first screen to maximize its usefulness.

### Information to Prioritize
For the app to be valuable, it should focus on the following pieces of information, which are critical for developers to manage their projects effectively:

- **Project Name**: This is the primary identifier for each project, making it easy for the developer to recognize their work at a glance.
- **Status**: Clearly indicate whether a project is **unfinished**, **dead**, or **finished**. This helps the developer quickly assess which projects require attention or can be ignored.
- **Last Launched Date**: Show the date when the project was last opened through the app. This provides insight into recent activity and helps prioritize tasks, reflecting the developer‚Äôs interaction with the project via this tool.
- **Project Path**: Store the file system path to the project directory. This is essential for enabling the "Launch in VS Code" feature, allowing seamless access to the project.

These elements ensure the app delivers concise, actionable data without overwhelming the user.

### UI Structure for the First Screen
The first screen should be clean, intuitive, and focused on providing an immediate overview of projects, with quick access to key actions for unfinished projects. Here‚Äôs how it should be structured:

#### **App Bar**
- **Title**: Display the app name (e.g., "Project Manager") to provide context.
- **Settings Icon**: Include an icon (e.g., a gear) on the right side that opens a settings page. This allows the developer to configure options like the VS Code executable path or app preferences.

#### **Filter Tabs**
- Provide a row of filter tabs below the app bar to sort projects by status:
  - **All**: Shows every project regardless of status.
  - **Unfinished**: Displays only unfinished projects (set as the default view).
  - **Dead**: Shows projects marked as dead.
  - **Finished**: Lists completed projects.
- **Default View**: Set to "Unfinished" since these are the projects most likely needing attention when the developer starts their device. This focuses the app on actionable tasks right away.

#### **Project Cards**
- Use a scrollable list of cards to display projects based on the selected filter. Each card should include:
  - **Project Name**: In bold text for emphasis and easy scanning.
  - **Status**: Displayed with color-coding for quick recognition:
    - Yellow for **unfinished** (indicating active work).
    - Red for **dead** (signaling abandonment).
    - Green for **finished** (showing completion).
  - **Last Launched Date**: Shown as "Last Launched: [date]" to indicate the last time the project was opened via the app.
  - **Actions for Unfinished Projects**:
    - **"Launch in VS Code" Button**: A button that opens the project directory in VS Code using the stored project path.
    - **Gravestone Icon**: A clickable icon (e.g., a tombstone) to mark the project as dead, updating its status in the database after a confirmation prompt.

#### **Optional Enhancements**
- **Search Bar**: Add a search field above the project list to let developers quickly find projects by name, enhancing usability for those with many projects.
- **Project Counters**: Display a count in the app bar or near the filter tabs (e.g., "Unfinished Projects: 5") to give an instant sense of workload.

### Why This Works
- **Prioritized Information**: The focus on project name, status, last launched date, and path ensures the developer gets the most relevant details without clutter. The "Last Launched" date, updated when a project is opened via the app, keeps the info practical and tied to app usage.
- **UI Design**: The app bar, filter tabs, and project cards create a structured, glanceable interface. Defaulting to unfinished projects aligns with the developer‚Äôs likely intent‚Äîstarting work‚Äîwhile color-coded statuses and action buttons make it fast and easy to act on projects.
- **Local Focus**: Since all operations are local, the SQLite database (with a simple table for id, name, status, path, and last_launched) and Flutter‚Äôs lightweight widgets ensure quick startup and responsiveness, fitting the autostart requirement.

This approach delivers a valuable tool that simplifies project management, keeps the developer focused, and integrates seamlessly into their workflow.

This helps the developer quickly assess which projects require att
headings: UI Structure for the First Screen
